License: CC BY 4.0
arXiv:2410.03706v1 [cs.LG] 25 Sep 2024

Topological Foundations of Reinforcement Learning

Krame Kadurha David
david.krame@aims-cameroon.org
African Institute for Mathematical Sciences (AIMS)
Cameroon
Supervised by: Dr. Yaé U. Gaba
AIMS-Research & Innovation Center (AIMS RIC)
Kigali, Rwanda
(18 May 2024
Submitted in Partial Fulfillment of a Structured Masters Degree at AIMS-Cameroon )

Abstract

The goal of this work is to serve as a foundation for deep studies of the topology of state, action, and policy spaces in reinforcement learning. By studying these spaces from a mathematical perspective, we expect to gain more insight into how to build better algorithms to solve decision problems. Therefore, we focus on presenting the connection between the Banach fixed point theorem and the convergence of reinforcement learning algorithms, and we illustrate how the insights gained from this can practically help in designing more efficient algorithms. Before doing so, however, we first introduce relevant concepts such as metric spaces, normed spaces and Banach spaces for better understanding, before expressing the entire reinforcement learning problem in terms of Markov decision processes. This allows us to properly introduce the Banach contraction principle in a language suitable for reinforcement learning, and to write the Bellman equations in terms of operators on Banach spaces to show why reinforcement learning algorithms converge. Finally, we show how the insights gained from the mathematical study of convergence are helpful in reasoning about the best ways to make reinforcement learning algorithms more efficient.

Keywords : Markov Decision Process; Reinforcement Learning; Contraction mapping; Fixed Point; Banach Space; Bellman Operators; Q-Learning.

Declaration

I, the undersigned, hereby declare that the work contained in this essay is my original work, and that any work done by others or by myself previously has been acknowledged and referenced accordingly.

 Krame Kadurha David, 18 May 2024.

Chapter 1 Introduction

There is not much work on the foundations of Reinforcement Learning (RL). Especially from a topological point of view. This work is, to the best of our knowledge, the first attempt to unify the basic concepts of Reinforcement Learning in a coherent and well-ordered way, specifying all the underlying mathematical concepts.

Some researchers have instead been interested in related questions, trying to explore RL concepts from a mathematical point of view, with the aim of improving the effectiveness of RL algorithms. For example:

In the paper [12], the authors studied the geometric and topological properties of the value functions in Markov decision processes with finite number of states and actions. Their characterization of the value function space as a general polytope provides an understanding of the relationships between policies and value functions. This perspective enhances the theoretical understanding of RL dynamics. The authors of [5] also explored the concept of Lipschitz continuity in model-based RL, emphasizing the importance of learning Lipschitz continuous models for efficient value function estimation. This establishes some error bounds and demonstrates the benefits of controlling the Lipschitz constant in RL setting. The work done in [34] extends model-free RL algorithms to continuous state-action spaces using a Q-learning-based approach, and that advancement opens avenues for applying RL techniques to a broader range of real-world applications with continuous state spaces. A very deep study is then done in [21], introducing a unified formalism for defining state similarity metrics in RL. The authors claim to address the challenge of generalization in continuous-state systems by establishing hierarchies among metrics and examining their implications on RL algorithms.
The aforementioned works can be difficult to understand or even less precise if the foundations are not well clarified. Therefore, the main goal of our work is to serve as a first stone in studying and organising the basic concepts, while presenting Reinforcement Learning in a simple and concise way, to help future researchers to quickly dive into the foundations of RL and to study more deeply, in particular the topology of state, action, and policy spaces. By studying these spaces from a mathematical perspective, we expect to gain more insight into how to build better algorithms to solve decision problems.
At the end of this work, we even illustrate the latter assumption by showing that, with the mathematical investigation we have done, we are able to make very strong and general conjectures which merit to be taken seriously into account. This work is organized then as follows :

After this introduction, in chapter 2, we discuss metric spaces and their completeness, as well as the Banach Fixed Point Theorem. We end the chapter giving an application of the Banach Fixed Point Theorem to a concrete example.

In chapter 3, we formally present the Markov Decision Process framework and directly after that, we present the concept of optimality in Reinforcement Learning. At the end, we then discuss some methods which are at the core of how optimality is attained in Reinforcement Learning.

In chapter 4, we express reinforcement in term of Operators to have a simple way of proving why Reinforcement Learning Algorithms work, using the Banach Contraction Principle. In fact, this chapter discusses about Bellman Operators and shows how the optimality can be reached using operators’ language.

Finally, before the final conclusion, in chapter 5 we present some limitations of the classical Bellman operator and, using some insights gained from the mathematical investigation done before, we propose an alternative to the classical Bellman operator which shows good behaviour in terms of optimality and efficiency.

Chapter 2 Metric spaces and the Banach fixed point

In this chapter, we present the fundamental concepts of metric spaces and explore their completeness, a crucial property in understanding the behavior of sequences within these spaces. We also study the Banach fixed point theorem, a result which establishes the existence and uniqueness of fixed points for mappings in complete metric spaces. We elucidate the significance of this theorem in providing a theoretical foundation for iterative algorithms and solution techniques in various mathematical and computational contexts. Furthermore, we culminate our discussion by illustrating the practical relevance of the Banach Fixed Point Theorem through a concrete example, demonstrating its applicability in solving real-world problems and providing insight into its computational implications.

2.1 Complete metric spaces

Metrics and metric spaces provide a structured framework for precisely measuring the relationship between elements within a set. This facilitates deeper insights into their interconnections and dependencies, enabling pattern recognition, association identification, and informed decision-making across diverse domains. In this section, we delve into complete metric spaces, which offer a comprehensive framework for understanding the entirety of a set’s elements and their interrelations.

2.1.1 Definition (Metric and metric space).

A metric on a set M𝑀Mitalic_M is a function d:M×M→ℝ:𝑑→𝑀𝑀ℝd:M\times M\rightarrow\mathbb{R}italic_d : italic_M × italic_M → blackboard_R, such that for x,y,z∈M𝑥𝑦𝑧𝑀x,y,z\in Mitalic_x , italic_y , italic_z ∈ italic_M:

  • (i)

    [Non-negativity] d⁢(x,y)≥0𝑑𝑥𝑦0d(x,y)\geq 0italic_d ( italic_x , italic_y ) ≥ 0 and d⁢(x,x)=0𝑑𝑥𝑥0d(x,x)=0italic_d ( italic_x , italic_x ) = 0

  • (ii)

    [Identity of indiscernibles] d⁢(x,y)=0⟹x=y𝑑𝑥𝑦0𝑥𝑦d(x,y)=0\implies x=yitalic_d ( italic_x , italic_y ) = 0 ⟹ italic_x = italic_y

  • (iii)

    [Symmetry] d⁢(x,y)=d⁢(y,x)𝑑𝑥𝑦𝑑𝑦𝑥d(x,y)=d(y,x)italic_d ( italic_x , italic_y ) = italic_d ( italic_y , italic_x )

  • (iv)

    [Triangle Inequality] d⁢(x,y)≤d⁢(x,z)+d⁢(z,y)𝑑𝑥𝑦𝑑𝑥𝑧𝑑𝑧𝑦d(x,y)\leq d(x,z)+d(z,y)italic_d ( italic_x , italic_y ) ≤ italic_d ( italic_x , italic_z ) + italic_d ( italic_z , italic_y )

The pair (M,d)𝑀𝑑(M,d)( italic_M , italic_d ) is called a metric space.

Let’s now give some interesting examples of metric spaces.

2.1.2 Example.

c

  • 1)

    Let M=ℝn𝑀superscriptℝ𝑛M=\mathbb{R}^{n}italic_M = blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT be the set of real n-uplets. For x=(x1,x2,⋯,xn)𝑥subscript𝑥1subscript𝑥2⋯subscript𝑥𝑛x=(x_{1},x_{2},\cdots,x_{n})italic_x = ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ⋯ , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , y=(y1,y2,⋯,yn)𝑦subscript𝑦1subscript𝑦2⋯subscript𝑦𝑛y=(y_{1},y_{2},\cdots,y_{n})italic_y = ( italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ⋯ , italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) and z=(z1,z2,⋯,zn)𝑧subscript𝑧1subscript𝑧2⋯subscript𝑧𝑛z=(z_{1},z_{2},\cdots,z_{n})italic_z = ( italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ⋯ , italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) in ℝnsuperscriptℝ𝑛\mathbb{R}^{n}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT let’s define :

    dp⁢(x,y)=(∑i=1n|xi−yi|p)1/p⁢with⁢p≥1subscript𝑑𝑝𝑥𝑦superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖subscript𝑦𝑖𝑝1𝑝with𝑝1d_{p}(x,y)=\Big{(}\sum_{i=1}^{n}|x_{i}-y_{i}|^{p}\Big{)}^{1/p}~{}~{}~{}\text{% with}~{}~{}p\geq 1italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x , italic_y ) = ( ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 / italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT with italic_p ≥ 1

    The conditions (i), (ii) and (iii) hold due to the properties of the absolute value and the triangle inequality also holds because it is the result of the Minkowsky’s inequality [19, 20]. Indeed assuming that ai=xi−zisubscript𝑎𝑖subscript𝑥𝑖subscript𝑧𝑖a_{i}=x_{i}-z_{i}italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and bi=zi−yisubscript𝑏𝑖subscript𝑧𝑖subscript𝑦𝑖b_{i}=z_{i}-y_{i}italic_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. We can write the triangle inequality as follows :

    (∑i=1n|ai+bi|p)1/p≤(∑i=1n|ai|p)1/p+(∑i=1n|bi|p)1/psuperscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑎𝑖subscript𝑏𝑖𝑝1𝑝superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑎𝑖𝑝1𝑝superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑏𝑖𝑝1𝑝\Big{(}\sum_{i=1}^{n}|a_{i}+b_{i}|^{p}\Big{)}^{1/p}\leq\Big{(}\sum_{i=1}^{n}|a% _{i}|^{p}\Big{)}^{1/p}+\Big{(}\sum_{i=1}^{n}|b_{i}|^{p}\Big{)}^{1/p}( ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 / italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ≤ ( ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 / italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + ( ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | italic_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 / italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT (2.1.1)

    So, (ℝn,dp)superscriptℝ𝑛subscript𝑑𝑝\Big{(}\mathbb{R}^{n},d_{p}\Big{)}( blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) is a metric space. When p=1𝑝1p=1italic_p = 1 we get the manhattan distance, if p=2𝑝2p=2italic_p = 2 we have the classical euclidian distance. But one case which is for a particular interest in this work is the case when p→∞→𝑝p\to\inftyitalic_p → ∞. We get the infinity distance :

    d∞⁢(x,y)=max1≤i≤n⁢|xi−yi|subscript𝑑𝑥𝑦1𝑖𝑛subscript𝑥𝑖subscript𝑦𝑖d_{\infty}(x,y)=\underset{1\leq i\leq n}{\max}~{}|x_{i}-y_{i}|italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∞ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x , italic_y ) = start_UNDERACCENT 1 ≤ italic_i ≤ italic_n end_UNDERACCENT start_ARG roman_max end_ARG | italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | (2.1.2)
  • 2)

    Let S𝑆Sitalic_S be any non-empty set and B⁢(S)𝐵𝑆B(S)italic_B ( italic_S ), the space of all bounded real-valued functions on S𝑆Sitalic_S. Consider f𝑓fitalic_f and g𝑔gitalic_g in B⁢(S)𝐵𝑆B(S)italic_B ( italic_S ), and define :

    d⁢(f,g)=s⁢u⁢px∈S⁢|f⁢(x)−g⁢(x)|𝑑𝑓𝑔𝑥𝑆𝑠𝑢𝑝𝑓𝑥𝑔𝑥d(f,g)=\underset{x\in S}{sup}~{}|f(x)-g(x)|italic_d ( italic_f , italic_g ) = start_UNDERACCENT italic_x ∈ italic_S end_UNDERACCENT start_ARG italic_s italic_u italic_p end_ARG | italic_f ( italic_x ) - italic_g ( italic_x ) | (2.1.3)

    The pair (B⁢(S),d)𝐵𝑆𝑑\Big{(}B(S),d\Big{)}( italic_B ( italic_S ) , italic_d ) is a metric space. This metric is called the supremum metric or uniform metric [20].

Having presented some interesting examples of metric spaces, we give some definitions and propositions, necessary to introduce the completeness of metric spaces.

2.1.3 Definition (Sequences).

A sequence in a metric space (X,d)𝑋𝑑(X,d)( italic_X , italic_d ) is a function u:ℕ→X:𝑢→ℕ𝑋u:\mathbb{N}\to Xitalic_u : blackboard_N → italic_X. It can be written {un}n∈ℕsubscriptsubscript𝑢𝑛𝑛ℕ\{u_{n}\}_{n\in\mathbb{N}}{ italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n ∈ blackboard_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT or just {un}subscript𝑢𝑛\{u_{n}\}{ italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT }.

2.1.4 Definition (Convergence).

A sequence {xn}subscript𝑥𝑛\{x_{n}\}{ italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } of points in (X,d)𝑋𝑑(X,d)( italic_X , italic_d ) is said to be convergent if there is a point x∗∈Xsuperscript𝑥𝑋x^{*}\in Xitalic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∈ italic_X such that, for any ε>0𝜀0\varepsilon>0italic_ε > 0, there exists a positive integer N0subscript𝑁0N_{0}italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT such that d⁢(xn,x∗)<ε𝑑subscript𝑥𝑛superscript𝑥𝜀d(x_{n},x^{*})<\varepsilonitalic_d ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) < italic_ε whenever n>N0𝑛subscript𝑁0n>N_{0}italic_n > italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. The point x∗superscript𝑥x^{*}italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is termed the limit of the sequence and we write xn→x∗→subscript𝑥𝑛superscript𝑥x_{n}\rightarrow x^{*}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT → italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

2.1.5 Proposition.

The limit of a sequence in a metric space is unique.

Proof.

The proof of that can be seen in [31]. It leverages the property that metric spaces belong to the family of T2subscript𝑇2T_{2}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (or Hausdorff) topological spaces ∎

Cauchy sequences play a fundamental role in the study of completeness within metric spaces. A sequence is considered Cauchy if, for any arbitrarily small positive distance, there exists a point in the sequence beyond which all subsequent points are within that distance from each other. Completeness, on the other hand, refers to the property of a metric space wherein every Cauchy sequence converges to a limit within the space itself. Together, Cauchy sequences and completeness provide essential tools for understanding the convergence behavior and structural integrity of metric spaces.

2.1.6 Definition (Cauchy sequences).

A sequence {xn}subscript𝑥𝑛\{x_{n}\}{ italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } in a metric space (X,d)𝑋𝑑\Big{(}X,d\Big{)}( italic_X , italic_d ) is called a Cauchy sequence if for any given ε>0𝜀0\varepsilon>0italic_ε > 0, we can find N0∈ℕsubscript𝑁0ℕN_{0}\in\mathbb{N}italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ blackboard_N such that whenever min⁡{m,n}>N0𝑚𝑛subscript𝑁0\min\{m,n\}>N_{0}roman_min { italic_m , italic_n } > italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT we have

d⁢(xm,xn)<ε.𝑑subscript𝑥𝑚subscript𝑥𝑛𝜀d(x_{m},x_{n})<\varepsilon.italic_d ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) < italic_ε .

While every convergent sequence is a Cauchy sequence, the reverse of this is only true in ‘complete metric spaces’.

2.1.7 Definition (Completeness).

The metric space (X,d)𝑋𝑑\Big{(}X,d\Big{)}( italic_X , italic_d ) is said complete if every Cauchy sequence converges in X𝑋Xitalic_X.

2.1.8 Example.

Using the standard metric (absolute value), ℝℝ\mathbb{R}blackboard_R is complete. Using also the associated standard metric, ℝnsuperscriptℝ𝑛\mathbb{R}^{n}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is complete [20].

2.1.9 Definition (Uniformly Cauchy sequence of functions).

We say that a sequence fn:X→ℝ:subscript𝑓𝑛→𝑋ℝf_{n}:X\rightarrow\mathbb{R}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT : italic_X → blackboard_R is uniformly Cauchy if for a given ε>0𝜀0\varepsilon>0italic_ε > 0, there exists N∈ℕ𝑁ℕN\in\mathbb{N}italic_N ∈ blackboard_N with the following property:

|fn⁢(x)−fm⁢(x)|<ε⁢for all⁢x∈X⁢and for all⁢m,n≥N.formulae-sequencesubscript𝑓𝑛𝑥subscript𝑓𝑚𝑥𝜀for all𝑥𝑋and for all𝑚𝑛𝑁|f_{n}(x)-f_{m}(x)|<\varepsilon~{}~{}\text{for all}~{}~{}x\in X~{}~{}\text{and% for all}~{}~{}m,n\geq N.| italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) - italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) | < italic_ε for all italic_x ∈ italic_X and for all italic_m , italic_n ≥ italic_N .

Normed spaces are a subset of metric spaces, where vectors have associated norms. They are useful because they provide a framework for measuring distances and magnitudes in vector spaces, aiding in the analysis of mathematical structures.

2.1.10 Definition (Norms and normed spaces).

Let’s V𝑉Vitalic_V be a linear space over a field 𝕂𝕂\mathbb{K}blackboard_K. A norm on V𝑉Vitalic_V is a map ||⋅||:V×V→ℝ+||\cdot||:V\times V\to\mathbb{R}^{+}| | ⋅ | | : italic_V × italic_V → blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT such that for any x,y∈V𝑥𝑦𝑉x,y\in Vitalic_x , italic_y ∈ italic_V and α∈𝕂𝛼𝕂\alpha\in\mathbb{K}italic_α ∈ blackboard_K :

  • (i)

    [Positivity] ‖x‖>0norm𝑥0~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}||x||>0| | italic_x | | > 0 for every x≠0𝑥0x\neq 0italic_x ≠ 0

  • (ii)

    [Homogeneity] ‖α⁢x‖=|α|⁢‖x‖norm𝛼𝑥𝛼norm𝑥~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}||\alpha x||=|\alpha|||x||| | italic_α italic_x | | = | italic_α | | | italic_x | |

  • (iii)

    [Triangle inequality] ‖x+y‖≤‖x‖+‖y‖norm𝑥𝑦norm𝑥norm𝑦~{}~{}||x+y||\leq||x||+||y||| | italic_x + italic_y | | ≤ | | italic_x | | + | | italic_y | |

The pair (V,||⋅||)\Big{(}V,||\cdot||\Big{)}( italic_V , | | ⋅ | | ) is called a normed space.

2.1.11 Remark.

While normed spaces focus on vector spaces and their associated norms, metric spaces provide a broader context for studying distances and relationships between points in arbitrary sets. If ||⋅||||\cdot||| | ⋅ | | is a norm, we can get a metric d𝑑ditalic_d from it by doing d⁢(x,y)=‖x−y‖𝑑𝑥𝑦norm𝑥𝑦d(x,y)=||x-y||italic_d ( italic_x , italic_y ) = | | italic_x - italic_y | |. This is called an induced metric.

2.1.12 Example.

Let X𝑋Xitalic_X be any nonempty set. Let us consider the linear space B⁢(X)𝐵𝑋B(X)italic_B ( italic_X ) of all bounded real valued functions on X𝑋Xitalic_X under the sup norm ||⋅||∞||\cdot||_{\infty}| | ⋅ | | start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∞ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. In B⁢(X)𝐵𝑋B(X)italic_B ( italic_X ), a sequence {fn}subscript𝑓𝑛\{f_{n}\}{ italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } is Cauchy if and only if it is uniformly Cauchy.

Proof.

Detailed proof in [38]. ∎

Banach spaces are a special class of normed vector spaces that are also complete metric spaces. This property of completeness ensures that every Cauchy sequence in the space will converge to a limit within the space itself, making Banach spaces crucial in various areas of analysis and functional analysis. Let now define the concept of Banach Space which will be important in the last chapter.

2.1.13 Definition.

A Banach space is a complete normed space.

2.1.14 Example.

The normed space (B(X),||⋅||∞)\left(B(X),||\cdot||_{\infty}\right)( italic_B ( italic_X ) , | | ⋅ | | start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∞ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) as defined in the Example 2.1.12 is a Banach space.

Proof.

The proof can be found in [20]. We here just sketch it.
Let {fn}∈B⁢(X)subscript𝑓𝑛𝐵𝑋\{f_{n}\}\in B(X){ italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } ∈ italic_B ( italic_X ) be a Cauchy sequence. By Example 2.1.12, the sequence {fn}subscript𝑓𝑛\{f_{n}\}{ italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } is uniformly Cauchy.

Let’s fix x∈X𝑥𝑋x\in Xitalic_x ∈ italic_X and consider the sequence of scalars {fn⁢(x)}subscript𝑓𝑛𝑥\{f_{n}(x)\}{ italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) }. Since ℝℝ\mathbb{R}blackboard_R is complete, the sequence converges to a real number f⁢(x)∈ℝ𝑓𝑥ℝf(x)\in\mathbb{R}italic_f ( italic_x ) ∈ blackboard_R.
First, we have to show that f𝑓fitalic_f is bounded on X𝑋Xitalic_X and,
Secondly we have to show that {fn}subscript𝑓𝑛\{f_{n}\}{ italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } converges uniformly to f𝑓fitalic_f on X𝑋Xitalic_X. That will complete the proof. ∎

Metric spaces are not always complete. We here present a way to make complete an incomplete metric space.

2.1.15 Completion of Metric Spaces [20, 31]

Let (X,d)𝑋𝑑(X,d)( italic_X , italic_d ) be a non-complete metric space. It is always possible to complete the space into a larger space in such a way that every Cauchy sequence in X has a limit in the completion. To do this, we should add new points to (X,d)𝑋𝑑(X,d)( italic_X , italic_d ) and extend d𝑑ditalic_d to all these new points so that each non-convergent Cauchy sequences in X𝑋Xitalic_X find limits among these new points.

2.1.16 Definition (Completion).

Let (X,d)𝑋𝑑(X,d)( italic_X , italic_d ) be a metric space. A complete metric space (X∗,d∗)superscript𝑋superscript𝑑(X^{*},d^{*})( italic_X start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) is considered as a completion of the metric space (X,d)𝑋𝑑(X,d)( italic_X , italic_d ) if :

  • (i)

    X𝑋Xitalic_X is a subspace of X∗superscript𝑋X^{*}italic_X start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT

  • (ii)

    Every point of X∗superscript𝑋X^{*}italic_X start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is the limit of some sequence in X𝑋Xitalic_X

2.1.17 Theorem.

Let (X,d)𝑋𝑑(X,d)( italic_X , italic_d ) be a metric space. Then there exists a completion of (X,d)𝑋𝑑(X,d)( italic_X , italic_d ).

Proof.

For the proof, see [20]. ∎

Let us now present the contraction mapping and the Banach Contraction Principle. Those are the core concepts that we will use throughout the work.

2.2 Contraction mapping and fixed-point

2.2.1 Definition.

Let X𝑋Xitalic_X be an nonempty set and f:X→X:𝑓→𝑋𝑋f:X\to Xitalic_f : italic_X → italic_X be a mapping on that set :

  • -

    A point x𝑥xitalic_x is said to be a fixed point of f𝑓fitalic_f if f⁢(x)=x𝑓𝑥𝑥f(x)=xitalic_f ( italic_x ) = italic_x.

  • -

    We will write F⁢i⁢x⁢(f)={x∈X:f⁢(x)=x}𝐹𝑖𝑥𝑓conditional-set𝑥𝑋𝑓𝑥𝑥Fix(f)=\{x\in X:f(x)=x\}italic_F italic_i italic_x ( italic_f ) = { italic_x ∈ italic_X : italic_f ( italic_x ) = italic_x } the set of fixed points of f𝑓fitalic_f on X𝑋Xitalic_X.

2.2.2 Proposition.

Let X𝑋Xitalic_X be a nonempty set and f:X→X:𝑓→𝑋𝑋f:X\to Xitalic_f : italic_X → italic_X a mapping defined on it. If x∈X𝑥𝑋x\in Xitalic_x ∈ italic_X is a unique fixed point of fnsuperscript𝑓𝑛f^{n}italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT with fn=f∘f∘⋯∘f⏟n−t⁢i⁢m⁢e⁢ssuperscript𝑓𝑛𝑛𝑡𝑖𝑚𝑒𝑠⏟𝑓𝑓⋯𝑓f^{n}=\underset{n-times}{\underbrace{f\circ f\circ\cdots\circ f}}italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = start_UNDERACCENT italic_n - italic_t italic_i italic_m italic_e italic_s end_UNDERACCENT start_ARG under⏟ start_ARG italic_f ∘ italic_f ∘ ⋯ ∘ italic_f end_ARG end_ARG for any n>1𝑛1n>1italic_n > 1, then it is the unique fixed point of f𝑓fitalic_f and reversely :

F⁢i⁢x⁢(fn)={x}⇔F⁢i⁢x⁢(f)={x}iff𝐹𝑖𝑥superscript𝑓𝑛𝑥𝐹𝑖𝑥𝑓𝑥Fix(f^{n})=\{x\}\iff Fix(f)=\{x\}italic_F italic_i italic_x ( italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = { italic_x } ⇔ italic_F italic_i italic_x ( italic_f ) = { italic_x }
Proof.

Let x𝑥xitalic_x be a fixed point for fnsuperscript𝑓𝑛f^{n}italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT in X𝑋Xitalic_X. Then we can write :

f⁢(x)=f⁢(fn⁢(x))=fn+1⁢(x)=fn⁢(f⁢(x))⟹f⁢(x)⁢is a fixed point of⁢fn𝑓𝑥𝑓superscript𝑓𝑛𝑥superscript𝑓𝑛1𝑥superscript𝑓𝑛𝑓𝑥𝑓𝑥is a fixed point ofsuperscript𝑓𝑛f(x)=f\left(f^{n}(x)\right)=f^{n+1}(x)=f^{n}\left(f(x)\right)\implies~{}~{}f(x% )~{}~{}\text{is a fixed point of}~{}~{}f^{n}italic_f ( italic_x ) = italic_f ( italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_x ) ) = italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_x ) = italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_f ( italic_x ) ) ⟹ italic_f ( italic_x ) is a fixed point of italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT

Since x𝑥xitalic_x is the only one fixed point for fnsuperscript𝑓𝑛f^{n}italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, then f⁢(x)=x𝑓𝑥𝑥f(x)=xitalic_f ( italic_x ) = italic_x, i.e. x𝑥xitalic_x is also a fixed point for f𝑓fitalic_f. Let’s now show that the aforementioned fixed point is unique also for f𝑓fitalic_f :
Let’s take y≠x𝑦𝑥y\neq xitalic_y ≠ italic_x another fixed point of f𝑓fitalic_f, and compute y=f⁢(y)=f2⁢(y)=⋯=fn⁢(y)𝑦𝑓𝑦superscript𝑓2𝑦⋯superscript𝑓𝑛𝑦y=f(y)=f^{2}(y)=\cdots=f^{n}(y)italic_y = italic_f ( italic_y ) = italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_y ) = ⋯ = italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_y ) or fn⁢(y)=y⇔y=xiffsuperscript𝑓𝑛𝑦𝑦𝑦𝑥f^{n}(y)=y\iff y=xitalic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_y ) = italic_y ⇔ italic_y = italic_x. Then, we’ve clearly seen that x𝑥xitalic_x is the unique fixed point for f𝑓fitalic_f. ∎

Before stating the Banach Contraction Principle, let’s define all the important notions related to that specific theorem.

2.2.3 Definition.

[13, 14, 26, 29] Let (X,d)𝑋𝑑(X,d)( italic_X , italic_d ) be a metric space and f:X→X:𝑓→𝑋𝑋f:X\to Xitalic_f : italic_X → italic_X a mapping on X𝑋Xitalic_X. f𝑓fitalic_f is said to be Lipschitz continuous if there exist α>0𝛼0\alpha>0italic_α > 0 such that :

d⁢(f⁢(x),f⁢(y))≤α⋅d⁢(x,y)⁢∀x,y∈Xformulae-sequence𝑑𝑓𝑥𝑓𝑦⋅𝛼𝑑𝑥𝑦for-all𝑥𝑦𝑋d\left(f(x),f(y)\right)\leq\alpha\cdot d(x,y)~{}~{}~{}\forall x,y\in Xitalic_d ( italic_f ( italic_x ) , italic_f ( italic_y ) ) ≤ italic_α ⋅ italic_d ( italic_x , italic_y ) ∀ italic_x , italic_y ∈ italic_X (2.2.1)
  • -

    If α∈[0,1)𝛼01\alpha\in[0,1)italic_α ∈ [ 0 , 1 ), f𝑓fitalic_f is said to be a contraction.

  • -

    If α=1𝛼1\alpha=1italic_α = 1 then f𝑓fitalic_f is said non-expansive.

  • -

    If d⁢(f⁢(x),f⁢(y))<d⁢(x,y),∀x≠yformulae-sequence𝑑𝑓𝑥𝑓𝑦𝑑𝑥𝑦for-all𝑥𝑦d\left(f(x),f(y)\right)<d(x,y),~{}\forall x\neq yitalic_d ( italic_f ( italic_x ) , italic_f ( italic_y ) ) < italic_d ( italic_x , italic_y ) , ∀ italic_x ≠ italic_y then f𝑓fitalic_f is contractive.

2.2.4 Proposition.

Let (X,d)𝑋𝑑(X,d)( italic_X , italic_d ) be a metric space and f:X→X:𝑓→𝑋𝑋f:X\to Xitalic_f : italic_X → italic_X a contraction mapping with α∈(0,1)𝛼01\alpha\in(0,1)italic_α ∈ ( 0 , 1 ). If f𝑓fitalic_f has a fixed point, that point is unique.

Proof.

Suppose we have two fixed points x𝑥xitalic_x and y𝑦yitalic_y for f𝑓fitalic_f with always x≠y𝑥𝑦x\neq yitalic_x ≠ italic_y. Because f𝑓fitalic_f is a contraction, with α∈(0,1)𝛼01\alpha\in(0,1)italic_α ∈ ( 0 , 1 ) we can write :

0≠d⁢(x,y)=d⁢(f⁢(x),f⁢(y))≤α⋅d⁢(x,y),0𝑑𝑥𝑦𝑑𝑓𝑥𝑓𝑦⋅𝛼𝑑𝑥𝑦0\neq d(x,y)=d\left(f(x),f(y)\right)\leq\alpha\cdot d(x,y),0 ≠ italic_d ( italic_x , italic_y ) = italic_d ( italic_f ( italic_x ) , italic_f ( italic_y ) ) ≤ italic_α ⋅ italic_d ( italic_x , italic_y ) ,

which is impossible (contradictory). So, the fixed point is unique. ∎

As we have now a formal definition of fixed point, contractions and some obvious implications, let’s now state the Banach Contraction Principle.

2.2.5 Theorem (Banach Contraction Principle : BCP [37]).

Let (X,d)𝑋𝑑(X,d)( italic_X , italic_d ) be a complete metric space, f:X→X:𝑓→𝑋𝑋f:X\to Xitalic_f : italic_X → italic_X a contraction. Then f𝑓fitalic_f has a unique fixed point x∗superscript𝑥x^{*}italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and for each x∈X𝑥𝑋x\in Xitalic_x ∈ italic_X, limn→∞fn⁢(x)=x∗subscript→𝑛superscript𝑓𝑛𝑥superscript𝑥\lim\limits_{n\to\infty}f^{n}(x)=x^{*}roman_lim start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n → ∞ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_x ) = italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Moreover,

d⁢(fn⁢(x),x∗)≤αn1−α⁢d⁢(x,f⁢(x)).𝑑superscript𝑓𝑛𝑥superscript𝑥superscript𝛼𝑛1𝛼𝑑𝑥𝑓𝑥d\left(f^{n}(x),x^{*}\right)\leq\dfrac{\alpha^{n}}{1-\alpha}d\left(x,f(x)% \right).italic_d ( italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_x ) , italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ≤ divide start_ARG italic_α start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 1 - italic_α end_ARG italic_d ( italic_x , italic_f ( italic_x ) ) .

.

Proof.

Let us construct a sequence {xn}subscript𝑥𝑛\{x_{n}\}{ italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT }, starting on x0subscript𝑥0x_{0}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and using the following recurrence :

xn=f⁢(xn−1)⁢∀n∈ℕ⁢i.e.⁢xn=fn⁢(x0)subscript𝑥𝑛𝑓subscript𝑥𝑛1for-all𝑛ℕi.e.subscript𝑥𝑛superscript𝑓𝑛subscript𝑥0x_{n}=f(x_{n-1})~{}~{}\forall n\in\mathbb{N}~{}~{}~{}\text{i.e.}~{}~{}~{}x_{n}% =f^{n}(x_{0})italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_f ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ∀ italic_n ∈ blackboard_N i.e. italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT )

We show that {xn}subscript𝑥𝑛\{x_{n}\}{ italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } is a Cauchy-Sequence. In fact, since f𝑓fitalic_f is a contraction, we should have :

d⁢(xm+1,xm)𝑑subscript𝑥𝑚1subscript𝑥𝑚\displaystyle d(x_{m+1},x_{m})italic_d ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) =d⁢(f⁢(xm),f⁢(xm−1))≤α⋅d⁢(xm,xm−1)absent𝑑𝑓subscript𝑥𝑚𝑓subscript𝑥𝑚1⋅𝛼𝑑subscript𝑥𝑚subscript𝑥𝑚1\displaystyle=d\left(f(x_{m}),f(x_{m-1})\right)\leq\alpha\cdot d(x_{m},x_{m-1})= italic_d ( italic_f ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , italic_f ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) ≤ italic_α ⋅ italic_d ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT )
=α⋅d⁢(f⁢(xm−1),f⁢(xm−2))≤α2⋅d⁢(xm−1,xm−2)absent⋅𝛼𝑑𝑓subscript𝑥𝑚1𝑓subscript𝑥𝑚2⋅superscript𝛼2𝑑subscript𝑥𝑚1subscript𝑥𝑚2\displaystyle=\alpha\cdot d\left(f(x_{m-1}),f(x_{m-2})\right)\leq\alpha^{2}% \cdot d(x_{m-1},x_{m-2})= italic_α ⋅ italic_d ( italic_f ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , italic_f ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m - 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) ≤ italic_α start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⋅ italic_d ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m - 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT )
⋮⋮\displaystyle\vdots⋮
=αm−1⋅d⁢(f⁢(x1),f⁢(x0))≤αm⋅d⁢(x1,x0)absent⋅superscript𝛼𝑚1𝑑𝑓subscript𝑥1𝑓subscript𝑥0⋅superscript𝛼𝑚𝑑subscript𝑥1subscript𝑥0\displaystyle=\alpha^{m-1}\cdot d\left(f(x_{1}),f(x_{0})\right)\leq\alpha^{m}% \cdot d(x_{1},x_{0})= italic_α start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_m - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⋅ italic_d ( italic_f ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , italic_f ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) ≤ italic_α start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⋅ italic_d ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) (2.2.2)

Now, for any given m𝑚mitalic_m and n𝑛nitalic_n, positive and with n<m𝑛𝑚n<mitalic_n < italic_m, the triangle inequality applied recursively gives :

d⁢(xm,xn)𝑑subscript𝑥𝑚subscript𝑥𝑛\displaystyle d(x_{m},x_{n})italic_d ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ≤d⁢(xm,xm−1)+d⁢(xm−1,xm−2)+⋯+d⁢(xn−1,xn)absent𝑑subscript𝑥𝑚subscript𝑥𝑚1𝑑subscript𝑥𝑚1subscript𝑥𝑚2⋯𝑑subscript𝑥𝑛1subscript𝑥𝑛\displaystyle\leq d(x_{m},x_{m-1})+d(x_{m-1},x_{m-2})+\cdots+d(x_{n-1},x_{n})≤ italic_d ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) + italic_d ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m - 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) + ⋯ + italic_d ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT )
≤(αm−1+αm−2+⋯+αn)⋅d⁢(x1,x0)⁢from 2.2absent⋅superscript𝛼𝑚1superscript𝛼𝑚2⋯superscript𝛼𝑛𝑑subscript𝑥1subscript𝑥0from 2.2\displaystyle\leq\left(\alpha^{m-1}+\alpha^{m-2}+\cdots+\alpha^{n}\right)\cdot d% (x_{1},x_{0})~{}~{}~{}\text{from \ref{eq : demons1}}≤ ( italic_α start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_m - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_α start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_m - 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + ⋯ + italic_α start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ⋅ italic_d ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) from
≤αn⁢(αm−n−1+αm−n−2+⋯+1)⋅d⁢(x1,x0)absent⋅superscript𝛼𝑛superscript𝛼𝑚𝑛1superscript𝛼𝑚𝑛2⋯1𝑑subscript𝑥1subscript𝑥0\displaystyle\leq\alpha^{n}\left(\alpha^{m-n-1}+\alpha^{m-n-2}+\cdots+1\right)% \cdot d(x_{1},x_{0})≤ italic_α start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_α start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_m - italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_α start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_m - italic_n - 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + ⋯ + 1 ) ⋅ italic_d ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT )
≤αn1−α⋅d⁢(x1,x0)absent⋅superscript𝛼𝑛1𝛼𝑑subscript𝑥1subscript𝑥0\displaystyle\leq\frac{\alpha^{n}}{1-\alpha}\cdot d(x_{1},x_{0})≤ divide start_ARG italic_α start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 1 - italic_α end_ARG ⋅ italic_d ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) (2.2.3)

As we can now see from limn→∞αn=0subscript→𝑛superscript𝛼𝑛0\lim\limits_{n\to\infty}\alpha^{n}=0roman_lim start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n → ∞ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_α start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 0 and d⁢(x1,x0)𝑑subscript𝑥1subscript𝑥0d(x_{1},x_{0})italic_d ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) is fixed, we can say d⁢(xm,xn)→0→𝑑subscript𝑥𝑚subscript𝑥𝑛0d(x_{m},x_{n})\to 0italic_d ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) → 0 as m,n→∞→𝑚𝑛m,n\to\inftyitalic_m , italic_n → ∞. So, {xn}subscript𝑥𝑛\{x_{n}\}{ italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } is a Cauchy sequence and since X𝑋Xitalic_X is complete, there exits only one x∗∈Xsuperscript𝑥𝑋x^{*}\in Xitalic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∈ italic_X such that xn→x∗→subscript𝑥𝑛superscript𝑥x_{n}\to x^{*}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT → italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. So, by continuity of contractions, we can write :

x∗=limn→∞xn+1=limn→∞f⁢(xn)=f⁢(limn→∞xn)=f⁢(limn→∞fn⁢(x0))=f⁢(x∗)superscript𝑥subscript→𝑛subscript𝑥𝑛1subscript→𝑛𝑓subscript𝑥𝑛𝑓subscript→𝑛subscript𝑥𝑛𝑓subscript→𝑛superscript𝑓𝑛subscript𝑥0𝑓superscript𝑥x^{*}=\lim\limits_{n\to\infty}x_{n+1}=\lim\limits_{n\to\infty}f(x_{n})=f\left(% \lim_{n\to\infty}x_{n}\right)=f\left(\lim_{n\to\infty}f^{n}(x_{0})\right)=f(x^% {*})italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = roman_lim start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n → ∞ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = roman_lim start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n → ∞ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = italic_f ( roman_lim start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n → ∞ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = italic_f ( roman_lim start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n → ∞ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) = italic_f ( italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT )

And the proposition above (Proposition 2.2.2), we have a way to find this unique fixed point independently on the starting point.
And to show a good estimate of how we are approaching the limit we can rewrite the Expression 2.2 like this :

d⁢(fn⁢(x),x∗)≤αn1−α⁢d⁢(x,f⁢(x))≡d⁢(xn,x∗)≤αn1−α⁢d⁢(x0,x1)𝑑superscript𝑓𝑛𝑥superscript𝑥superscript𝛼𝑛1𝛼𝑑𝑥𝑓𝑥𝑑subscript𝑥𝑛superscript𝑥superscript𝛼𝑛1𝛼𝑑subscript𝑥0subscript𝑥1d\left(f^{n}(x),x^{*}\right)\leq\dfrac{\alpha^{n}}{1-\alpha}d\left(x,f(x)% \right)~{}~{}~{}\equiv~{}~{}~{}d\left(x_{n},x^{*}\right)\leq\dfrac{\alpha^{n}}% {1-\alpha}d\left(x_{0},x_{1}\right)italic_d ( italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_x ) , italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ≤ divide start_ARG italic_α start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 1 - italic_α end_ARG italic_d ( italic_x , italic_f ( italic_x ) ) ≡ italic_d ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ≤ divide start_ARG italic_α start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 1 - italic_α end_ARG italic_d ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT )

∎

2.2.6 Remark.

The beauty of the Banach Contraction Principle is that it only require completeness for the metric space and contraction property on the mapping. Also, we can get closer and closer to the fixed point, starting from any point x≡x0∈X𝑥subscript𝑥0𝑋x\equiv x_{0}\in Xitalic_x ≡ italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ italic_X by just applying recursively the mapping on that specific point.

2.3 Application of the Banach Contraction Principle - An example

The Banach Fixed Point principle or Banach Contraction Principle (BCP) is very important in many fields, in mathematics as well as in its applications [3, 24, 38, 43]. We here introduce a problem whose solution is guaranteed by the Picard-Lindelof Theorem, the uniqueness of solutions of a first order Ordinary Differential Equation (ODE). We show that its solution can be obtained using the BCP.
Let’s say we have the following initial value problem (which is here an ODE with initial conditions) :

y′=F⁢(x,y);y⁢(x0)=y0⁢with⁢y′=d⁢yd⁢xformulae-sequencesuperscript𝑦′𝐹𝑥𝑦𝑦subscript𝑥0subscript𝑦0withsuperscript𝑦′𝑑𝑦𝑑𝑥y^{\prime}=F(x,y)~{}~{}~{};~{}~{}~{}y(x_{0})=y_{0}~{}~{}~{}\text{with}~{}~{}y^% {\prime}=\dfrac{dy}{dx}italic_y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_F ( italic_x , italic_y ) ; italic_y ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT with italic_y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = divide start_ARG italic_d italic_y end_ARG start_ARG italic_d italic_x end_ARG (2.3.1)

This problem is in fact equivalent to the following :

y⁢(x)−y⁢(x0)𝑦𝑥𝑦subscript𝑥0\displaystyle y(x)-y(x_{0})italic_y ( italic_x ) - italic_y ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) =∫x0xF⁢(t,y⁢(t))⁢𝑑t⁢as we have y0=y⁢(x0)absentsuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑥0𝑥𝐹𝑡𝑦𝑡differential-d𝑡as we have y0=y⁢(x0)\displaystyle=\int_{x_{0}}^{x}F\Big{(}t,y(t)\Big{)}dt~{}~{}\text{as we have $y% _{0}=y(x_{0})$}= ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_F ( italic_t , italic_y ( italic_t ) ) italic_d italic_t as we have italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_y ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT )
⇒y⁢(x)⇒absent𝑦𝑥\displaystyle\Rightarrow y(x)⇒ italic_y ( italic_x ) =y0+∫x0xF⁢(t,y⁢(t))⁢𝑑tabsentsubscript𝑦0superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑥0𝑥𝐹𝑡𝑦𝑡differential-d𝑡\displaystyle=y_{0}+\int_{x_{0}}^{x}F\Big{(}t,y(t)\Big{)}dt= italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_F ( italic_t , italic_y ( italic_t ) ) italic_d italic_t (2.3.2)

So, the two problems 2.3.1 and 2.3.2 are exactly the same. And from this last Expression 2.3.2 we can define a sequence given by :

yn+1⁢(x)=y0+∫x0xF⁢(t,yn⁢(t))⁢𝑑t⁢with y0=yn⁢(x0)⁢∀n.subscript𝑦𝑛1𝑥subscript𝑦0superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑥0𝑥𝐹𝑡subscript𝑦𝑛𝑡differential-d𝑡with y0=yn⁢(x0)⁢∀n.y_{n+1}(x)=y_{0}+\int_{x_{0}}^{x}F\Big{(}t,y_{n}(t)\Big{)}dt~{}~{}~{}\text{% with $y_{0}=y_{n}(x_{0})~{}~{}\forall~{}n$.}italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) = italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_F ( italic_t , italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t ) ) italic_d italic_t with italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ∀ italic_n . (2.3.3)

The problem can be seen as demonstrating the Picard-Lindelof Theorem which states the following :

2.3.1 Theorem (Picard-Lindelof Theorem [27]).

Let D⊂ℝ×ℝn𝐷ℝsuperscriptℝ𝑛D\subset\mathbb{R}\times\mathbb{R}^{n}italic_D ⊂ blackboard_R × blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT be an open set, F:D→ℝn:𝐹→𝐷superscriptℝ𝑛F:D\to\mathbb{R}^{n}italic_F : italic_D → blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT a continuous function and (x0,𝐲0)∈Dsubscript𝑥0subscript𝐲0𝐷(x_{0},\mathbf{y}_{0})\in D( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ∈ italic_D. Then the initial value problem

d⁢𝐲d⁢x=y′=f⁢(x,𝐲),𝐲⁢(x0)=𝐲0formulae-sequence𝑑𝐲𝑑𝑥superscript𝑦′𝑓𝑥𝐲𝐲subscript𝑥0subscript𝐲0\frac{d\mathbf{y}}{dx}=y^{\prime}=f(x,\mathbf{y}),\quad\mathbf{y}(x_{0})=% \mathbf{y}_{0}divide start_ARG italic_d bold_y end_ARG start_ARG italic_d italic_x end_ARG = italic_y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_f ( italic_x , bold_y ) , bold_y ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = bold_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT

has a unique solution 𝐲⁢(x)𝐲𝑥\mathbf{y}(x)bold_y ( italic_x ) on closed intervals I=[x0−ε,x0+ε]𝐼subscript𝑥0𝜀subscript𝑥0𝜀I=[x_{0}-\varepsilon,x_{0}+\varepsilon]italic_I = [ italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_ε , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_ε ] with ε>0𝜀0\varepsilon>0italic_ε > 0.

To easily show the usefulness of the BCP for the problem 2.3.1, we can enunciate the Picard-Lindelof Theorem in especially the context of that problem as follows and then prove the existence and uniqueness of the solution :

2.3.2 Proposition.

[43]    Assume that :

  1. 1.

    With S𝑆Sitalic_S a rectangle domain defined as follows

    S={(x,w)∈ℝ2:|x−x0|≤a⁢and⁢|w−y0|≤b}⁢with a,b∈ℝ and w=y⁢(x)𝑆conditional-set𝑥𝑤superscriptℝ2𝑥subscript𝑥0𝑎and𝑤subscript𝑦0𝑏with a,b∈ℝ and w=y⁢(x)S=\{(x,w)\in\mathbb{R}^{2}:|x-x_{0}|\leq a~{}~{}\text{and}~{}~{}|w-y_{0}|\leq b% \}~{}~{}\text{with $a,b\in\mathbb{R}$ and $w=y(x)$}italic_S = { ( italic_x , italic_w ) ∈ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT : | italic_x - italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | ≤ italic_a and | italic_w - italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | ≤ italic_b } with italic_a , italic_b ∈ blackboard_R and italic_w = italic_y ( italic_x )

    The function F:S→ℝ:𝐹→𝑆ℝF:S\to\mathbb{R}italic_F : italic_S → blackboard_R, given in the ODE 2.3.1 above, is continuous, and there exists c∈ℝ+𝑐superscriptℝc\in\mathbb{R}^{+}italic_c ∈ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT such that |F⁢(x,y)|≤c.𝐹𝑥𝑦𝑐|F(x,y)|\leq c.| italic_F ( italic_x , italic_y ) | ≤ italic_c .

  2. 2.

    F⁢(x,y)𝐹𝑥𝑦F(x,y)italic_F ( italic_x , italic_y ) satisfies the Lipschitz condition with respect to y𝑦yitalic_y on S𝑆Sitalic_S, i.e. there exists L≥0𝐿0L\geq 0italic_L ≥ 0 such that :

    |F⁢(x,y1⁢(x))−F⁢(x,y2⁢(x))|≤L⋅|y1⁢(x)−y2⁢(x)|,for all⁢(x,y1),(x,y2)∈Sformulae-sequence𝐹𝑥subscript𝑦1𝑥𝐹𝑥subscript𝑦2𝑥⋅𝐿subscript𝑦1𝑥subscript𝑦2𝑥for all𝑥subscript𝑦1𝑥subscript𝑦2𝑆|F(x,y_{1}(x))-F(x,y_{2}(x))|\leq L\cdot|y_{1}(x)-y_{2}(x)|,~{}~{}~{}\text{for% all}~{}~{}(x,y_{1}),(x,y_{2})\in S| italic_F ( italic_x , italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) ) - italic_F ( italic_x , italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) ) | ≤ italic_L ⋅ | italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) - italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) | , for all ( italic_x , italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , ( italic_x , italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ∈ italic_S
  3. 3.

    The real number hℎhitalic_h satisfies : 0<h≤a,h⁢c≤b,h⁢L≤1formulae-sequence0ℎ𝑎formulae-sequenceℎ𝑐𝑏ℎ𝐿10<h\leq a,~{}~{}hc\leq b,~{}~{}hL\leq 10 < italic_h ≤ italic_a , italic_h italic_c ≤ italic_b , italic_h italic_L ≤ 1

The following holds :

  • (i)

    The sequence {yn}subscript𝑦𝑛\{y_{n}\}{ italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } constructed in Relation 2.3.3 converges to a certain function y∗subscript𝑦y_{*}italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

  • (ii)

    The initial value problem stated in 2.3.1 and equivalently in its integrale form given by the Expression 2.3.2 has a unique solution which is exactly y∗subscript𝑦y_{*}italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

  • (iii)

    For n∈ℕ𝑛ℕn\in\mathbb{N}italic_n ∈ blackboard_N and k:=h⁢Lassign𝑘ℎ𝐿k:=hLitalic_k := italic_h italic_L we have the following estimates :

    • ∙∙\bullet∙

      ‖yn−y∗‖∞≤kn1−k⋅‖y1−y0‖∞subscriptnormsubscript𝑦𝑛subscript𝑦⋅superscript𝑘𝑛1𝑘subscriptnormsubscript𝑦1subscript𝑦0||y_{n}-y_{*}||_{\infty}\leq\dfrac{k^{n}}{1-k}\cdot||y_{1}-y_{0}||_{\infty}| | italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | | start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∞ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≤ divide start_ARG italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 1 - italic_k end_ARG ⋅ | | italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | | start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∞ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT see the last Expression 2.2.

    • ∙∙\bullet∙

      ‖yn+1−y∗‖∞≤k1−k⋅‖yn+1−yn‖∞subscriptnormsubscript𝑦𝑛1subscript𝑦⋅𝑘1𝑘subscriptnormsubscript𝑦𝑛1subscript𝑦𝑛||y_{n+1}-y_{*}||_{\infty}\leq\dfrac{k}{1-k}\cdot||y_{n+1}-y_{n}||_{\infty}| | italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | | start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∞ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≤ divide start_ARG italic_k end_ARG start_ARG 1 - italic_k end_ARG ⋅ | | italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | | start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∞ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT

We will not prove this proposition explicitly. We will follow a process, inspired with the assumptions made in the Proposition 2.3.2 and that will help us to demonstrate immediately (i)i(\textit{i})( i ) and (ii)ii(\textit{ii})( ii ). The point (iii)iii(\textit{iii})( iii ) about the estimates will follow immediately, due to the Expression 2.2.

Proof.

Let R𝑅Ritalic_R be the rectangular domain :

R={(x,w)∈ℝ2:|x−x0|≤h⁢and⁢|w−y0|≤h.c}⁢with h,c∈ℝ and w=y⁢(x)𝑅conditional-set𝑥𝑤superscriptℝ2formulae-sequence𝑥subscript𝑥0ℎand𝑤subscript𝑦0ℎ𝑐with h,c∈ℝ and w=y⁢(x)R=\{(x,w)\in\mathbb{R}^{2}:|x-x_{0}|\leq h~{}~{}\text{and}~{}~{}|w-y_{0}|\leq h% .c\}~{}~{}\text{with $h,c\in\mathbb{R}$ and $w=y(x)$}italic_R = { ( italic_x , italic_w ) ∈ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT : | italic_x - italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | ≤ italic_h and | italic_w - italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | ≤ italic_h . italic_c } with italic_h , italic_c ∈ blackboard_R and italic_w = italic_y ( italic_x )

Following the assumptions made for this Proposition, we know that 0<h≤a,h⁢c≤bformulae-sequence0ℎ𝑎ℎ𝑐𝑏0<h\leq a,~{}~{}hc\leq b0 < italic_h ≤ italic_a , italic_h italic_c ≤ italic_b, i.e. R⊂S𝑅𝑆R\subset Sitalic_R ⊂ italic_S.
Let X𝑋Xitalic_X be the set of all real-valued continuous functions y=y⁢(x)𝑦𝑦𝑥y=y(x)italic_y = italic_y ( italic_x ) on [x0−h,x0+h]subscript𝑥0ℎsubscript𝑥0ℎ[x_{0}-h,x_{0}+h][ italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_h , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_h ]. Then X𝑋Xitalic_X is a closed subset of the normed space 𝒞⁢([x0−h,x0+h])𝒞subscript𝑥0ℎsubscript𝑥0ℎ\mathcal{C}\left([x_{0}-h,x_{0}+h]\right)caligraphic_C ( [ italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_h , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_h ] ) with the sup norm ||⋅||∞||\cdot||_{\infty}| | ⋅ | | start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∞ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.
Let’s now define an operator (a functional) like this (inspired by the second formulation of our problem, given in 2.3.2) :

T:X→:𝑇→𝑋absent\displaystyle T:X\toitalic_T : italic_X → X𝑋\displaystyle Xitalic_X
g⁢(x)↦maps-to𝑔𝑥absent\displaystyle g(x)\mapstoitalic_g ( italic_x ) ↦ h⁢(x)=T⁢g=y0+∫x0xF⁢(t,g⁢(t))⁢𝑑tℎ𝑥𝑇𝑔subscript𝑦0superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑥0𝑥𝐹𝑡𝑔𝑡differential-d𝑡\displaystyle h(x)=Tg=y_{0}+\int_{x_{0}}^{x}F\Big{(}t,g(t)\Big{)}dtitalic_h ( italic_x ) = italic_T italic_g = italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_F ( italic_t , italic_g ( italic_t ) ) italic_d italic_t (2.3.4)

Since

d⁢(h⁢(x),y0)=sup𝑥⁢|∫x0xF⁢(t,g⁢(t))⁢𝑑t|=‖∫x0xF⁢(t,g⁢(t))⁢𝑑t‖∞≤c⁢(x−x0)≤c⋅h≤b,𝑑ℎ𝑥subscript𝑦0𝑥supremumsuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑥0𝑥𝐹𝑡𝑔𝑡differential-d𝑡subscriptnormsuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑥0𝑥𝐹𝑡𝑔𝑡differential-d𝑡𝑐𝑥subscript𝑥0⋅𝑐ℎ𝑏d\Big{(}h(x),y_{0}\Big{)}=\underset{x}{\sup}{\left|\int_{x_{0}}^{x}F\Big{(}t,g% (t)\Big{)}dt\right|}=\left|\left|\int_{x_{0}}^{x}F\Big{(}t,g(t)\Big{)}dt\right% |\right|_{\infty}\leq c(x-x_{0})\leq c\cdot h\leq b,italic_d ( italic_h ( italic_x ) , italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = underitalic_x start_ARG roman_sup end_ARG | ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_F ( italic_t , italic_g ( italic_t ) ) italic_d italic_t | = | | ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_F ( italic_t , italic_g ( italic_t ) ) italic_d italic_t | | start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∞ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≤ italic_c ( italic_x - italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ≤ italic_c ⋅ italic_h ≤ italic_b ,

we can say that the operator T𝑇Titalic_T in 2.3.4 is well defined.
Now, we have to prove that this operator is a contraction mapping. For that, let’s take g,g1∈X𝑔subscript𝑔1𝑋g,g_{1}\in Xitalic_g , italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ italic_X. We’ll have :

d⁢(T⁢g,T⁢g1)=d⁢(h,h1)=𝑑𝑇𝑔𝑇subscript𝑔1𝑑ℎsubscriptℎ1absent\displaystyle d\left(Tg,Tg_{1}\right)=d(h,h_{1})=italic_d ( italic_T italic_g , italic_T italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = italic_d ( italic_h , italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = ‖∫x0x(F⁢(t,g⁢(t))−F⁢(t,g1⁢(t)))⁢𝑑t‖∞subscriptnormsuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑥0𝑥𝐹𝑡𝑔𝑡𝐹𝑡subscript𝑔1𝑡differential-d𝑡\displaystyle~{}~{}\left|\left|\int_{x_{0}}^{x}\Big{(}F\left(t,g(t)\right)-F% \left(t,g_{1}(t)\right)\Big{)}dt\right|\right|_{\infty}| | ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_F ( italic_t , italic_g ( italic_t ) ) - italic_F ( italic_t , italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t ) ) ) italic_d italic_t | | start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∞ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT
≤\displaystyle\leq≤ ∫x0x‖(F⁢(t,g⁢(t))−F⁢(t,g1⁢(t)))‖∞⁢𝑑tsuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑥0𝑥subscriptnorm𝐹𝑡𝑔𝑡𝐹𝑡subscript𝑔1𝑡differential-d𝑡\displaystyle~{}~{}\int_{x_{0}}^{x}\left|\left|\Big{(}F\left(t,g(t)\right)-F% \left(t,g_{1}(t)\right)\Big{)}\right|\right|_{\infty}dt∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | | ( italic_F ( italic_t , italic_g ( italic_t ) ) - italic_F ( italic_t , italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t ) ) ) | | start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∞ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d italic_t
≤\displaystyle\leq≤ L⋅∫x0x|g⁢(t)−g1⁢(t)|⁢𝑑t⁢ using the second assumption.⋅𝐿superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑥0𝑥𝑔𝑡subscript𝑔1𝑡differential-d𝑡 using the second assumption.\displaystyle~{}~{}L\cdot\int_{x_{0}}^{x}\left|g(t)-g_{1}(t)\right|dt\text{~{}% ~{}~{}using the second assumption.}italic_L ⋅ ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | italic_g ( italic_t ) - italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t ) | italic_d italic_t using the second assumption.
≤\displaystyle\leq≤ L⁢h⋅d⁢(g,g1)=k⋅d⁢(g,g1).⋅𝐿ℎ𝑑𝑔subscript𝑔1⋅𝑘𝑑𝑔subscript𝑔1\displaystyle~{}~{}Lh\cdot d\left(g,g_{1}\right)=k\cdot d\left(g,g_{1}\right).italic_L italic_h ⋅ italic_d ( italic_g , italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = italic_k ⋅ italic_d ( italic_g , italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) . (2.3.5)

In 2.3.5, from the third assumption, we know that k<1𝑘1k<1italic_k < 1, then the operator T𝑇Titalic_T is a contraction.
Hence now T𝑇Titalic_T is a contraction mapping and X is a closed subset of a metric space, X𝑋Xitalic_X is also a complete metric space and by the Banach Fixed Point principle, T𝑇Titalic_T has one unique fixed point g𝑔gitalic_g which is the exactly the unique solution to the given ODE. ∎

2.3.3 Example.

Consider the following first order initial value problem

x′⁢(t)=12⁢x⁢(t)−t,x⁢(0)=0.formulae-sequencesuperscript𝑥′𝑡12𝑥𝑡𝑡𝑥00x^{\prime}(t)=\frac{1}{2}x(t)-t,~{}~{}~{}~{}x(0)=0.italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG italic_x ( italic_t ) - italic_t , italic_x ( 0 ) = 0 .

From the Picard-Lindelof Theorem above, we are sure that we’ll get a solution, and to converge to it, we started with a random function and used an iterative approach, as suggested by the Banach contraction principle that we used to prove the theorem (through the Proposition 2.3.2). We obtained the following results :

In the Figure 2.1 we can see that the algorithm converges quickly to the true function (just after 5 iterations on [0,4]04[0,4][ 0 , 4 ]. To make it work, we implemented the operator 2.3.4 and used the same kind of iterative process as suggested by the Banach contraction principle. The full implementation we did, as well as the use of other methods for validation and stability, can be seen in our Github [1]. The Example 2.3.3 has also been treated in [16] and the interested reader can compare our results with those found in that article.

Chapter Conclusion

In this chapter we have discussed contraction mappings in a metric space and the Banach contraction principle (or Banach fixed point theorem). We have also shown how the theorem can be used to prove the existence and uniqueness of solutions to first-order ordinary differential equations with initial conditions, and even to find the solution. In the next chapter we will give an overview of Reinforcement Learning, which will help us to relate it to the theories introduced in this chapter.

Chapter 3 Overview on Reinforcement Learning

In this chapter, we will first formally present the Markov Decision Process framework and how it relates to Reinforcement Learning. Second, we will talk about optimality in Reinforcement Learning, and finally we will discuss some methods that are at the core of how optimality is realised in Reinforcement Learning.

3.1 Markov Decision Processes in the Reinforcement Learning setting

We here present a formal definition of the Markov Decision Process. But before that, we discuss about Markov Chain because it allows us to present the fact that, there are situations in which the previous observation contains all the information about the past, in such a way that we don’t need to look at the whole history.

3.1.1 Definition (Markov chain [22]).

Let 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S}caligraphic_S (a subset of ℝnsuperscriptℝ𝑛\mathbb{R}^{n}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT for example) represent the state space. The discrete-time dynamic system {St}t∈ℕ∈𝒮subscriptsubscript𝑆𝑡𝑡ℕ𝒮\{S_{t}\}_{t\in\mathbb{N}}\in\mathcal{S}{ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t ∈ blackboard_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ caligraphic_S is a Markov chain if :

ℙ⁢(St+1=s|St,St−1,⋯,S0)=ℙ⁢(St+1=s|St),ℙsubscript𝑆𝑡1conditional𝑠subscript𝑆𝑡subscript𝑆𝑡1⋯subscript𝑆0ℙsubscript𝑆𝑡1conditional𝑠subscript𝑆𝑡\mathbb{P}(S_{t+1}=s|S_{t},S_{t-1},\cdots,S_{0})=\mathbb{P}(S_{t+1}=s|S_{t}),blackboard_P ( italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_s | italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ⋯ , italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = blackboard_P ( italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_s | italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , (3.1.1)

i.e. everything we need to predict (in probability) the future is contained in the current state (this is what we call Markov property). Given an initial state S0∈𝒮subscript𝑆0𝒮S_{0}\in\mathcal{S}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ caligraphic_S, a Markov chain is defined by the following transition probability :

p⁢(s′|s)=P⁢r⁢(St+1=s′|St=s).𝑝conditionalsuperscript𝑠′𝑠𝑃𝑟subscript𝑆𝑡1conditionalsuperscript𝑠′subscript𝑆𝑡𝑠p(s^{\prime}|s)=Pr(S_{t+1}=s^{\prime}|S_{t}=s).italic_p ( italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | italic_s ) = italic_P italic_r ( italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_s ) . (3.1.2)

We can now clearly define the Markov Decision Process and related concepts, important for Reinforcement Learning.

3.1.2 Definition (Markov Decision Process [22, 32]).

Formally, an Markov Decision Process (MDP) is a 5-uplet ℳ=⟨𝒮,𝒜,p,r,γ⟩ℳ𝒮𝒜𝑝𝑟𝛾\mathcal{M}=\langle\mathcal{S},\mathcal{A},p,r,\gamma\ranglecaligraphic_M = ⟨ caligraphic_S , caligraphic_A , italic_p , italic_r , italic_γ ⟩ where :

  • •

    𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S}caligraphic_S represents the state space. It can be finite, countable infinite or continuous.

  • •

    𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A}caligraphic_A represents the action space which could also be finite, countable infinite or continuous.

  • •

    p⁢(s,a,s′)𝑝𝑠𝑎superscript𝑠′p(s,a,s^{\prime})italic_p ( italic_s , italic_a , italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) is the transition probability (called environment dynamics) defined by :

    p(s,a,s′)≡p(s′|s,a)=Pr(St+1=s′|St=s,At=a),p(s,a,s^{\prime})\equiv p(s^{\prime}|s,a)=Pr(S_{t+1}=s^{\prime}|S_{t}=s,A_{t}=% a),italic_p ( italic_s , italic_a , italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ≡ italic_p ( italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | italic_s , italic_a ) = italic_P italic_r ( italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_s , italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_a ) , (3.1.3)

    with s,s′∈𝒮𝑠superscript𝑠′𝒮s,s^{\prime}\in\mathcal{S}italic_s , italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∈ caligraphic_S and a∈𝒜𝑎𝒜a\in\mathcal{A}italic_a ∈ caligraphic_A. This represents the probability of observing a next state s′superscript𝑠′s^{\prime}italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT when the action a𝑎aitalic_a is taken in the state s𝑠sitalic_s.

  • •

    r⁢(s,a,s′)𝑟𝑠𝑎superscript𝑠′r(s,a,s^{\prime})italic_r ( italic_s , italic_a , italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) is the reward function called also a reinforcement obtained when taking the action a𝑎aitalic_a, in the state s𝑠sitalic_s and the next state observed is s′superscript𝑠′s^{\prime}italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. So :

    r:𝒮×𝒜×𝒮→ℝ:𝑟→𝒮𝒜𝒮ℝr:\mathcal{S}\times\mathcal{A}\times\mathcal{S}\to\mathbb{R}italic_r : caligraphic_S × caligraphic_A × caligraphic_S → blackboard_R
  • •

    The transition probability p𝑝pitalic_p and the reward function r𝑟ritalic_r defines the environment model.

  • •

    γ∈[0,1)𝛾01\gamma\in[0,1)italic_γ ∈ [ 0 , 1 ) is the discount factor used to define (let’s say for discrete time here for illustration) the expected cumulative reward :

    G=∑t=0∞γt⋅r⁢(St,At,St+1).𝐺superscriptsubscript𝑡0⋅superscript𝛾𝑡𝑟subscript𝑆𝑡subscript𝐴𝑡subscript𝑆𝑡1G=\sum_{t=0}^{\infty}\gamma^{t}\cdot r(S_{t},A_{t},S_{t+1}).italic_G = ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t = 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∞ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_γ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⋅ italic_r ( italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) .

If we have a problem which can be modeled as an MDP, the goal is generally to maximize the quantity G𝐺Gitalic_G by choosing at each time and for each state the action Atsubscript𝐴𝑡A_{t}italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. That choice is defined by a function π:𝒮→Δ⁢𝒜:𝜋→𝒮Δ𝒜\pi:\mathcal{S}\to\Delta\mathcal{A}italic_π : caligraphic_S → roman_Δ caligraphic_A called policy. Where Δ⁢𝒜Δ𝒜\Delta\mathcal{A}roman_Δ caligraphic_A represents a probability distribution under actions.

3.1.3 Definition (Policy or decision rule).

Policy is a mapping of states to actions, which can be :

  • •

    Deterministic : in the same conditions, the same action is always chosen.

  • •

    Stochastic : at each time, actions are only chosen with a certain probability. In this case the policy is a mapping from the state space to a probability distribution over actions.

The policy can also be varying as the time evolve (Non-stationary policy) or constant (Stationary policy).

We have given the foundational definitions, let us now reformulate everything in the Reinforcement Learning setting :

  1. 1.

    The agent-environment interface
    Markov Decision Processes (MDPs) are indeed a simple way to frame the problem of learning from interaction to achieve a goal. We are here define some important terms in the field of Reinforcement Learning :

    • •

      The element that has to learn and make decisions is called agent.

    • •

      Everything with which the agent interacts, including any entity outside the agent, is called the environment.

    • •

      The agent and the environment are in constant interaction, the former selecting actions, the latter responding to those actions and presenting new situations to the agent. These new situations are called states of the environment.

    • •

      The agent also receives rewards (special numerical values) from the environment and tries to maximise these over time through its choice of actions.

    • •

      We call action the way the agent chooses to interact with its environment. Or simply, the interaction of the agent with its environment.

    Let us now call Stsubscript𝑆𝑡S_{t}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, Atsubscript𝐴𝑡A_{t}italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Rtsubscript𝑅𝑡R_{t}italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT respectively the state, the action and the reward at a specific time-step t𝑡titalic_t.The MDP and the agent will now produce the following kind of sequences :

    S0,A0,R1,S1,A1,R2,S2,A2,R3,…subscript𝑆0subscript𝐴0subscript𝑅1subscript𝑆1subscript𝐴1subscript𝑅2subscript𝑆2subscript𝐴2subscript𝑅3…S_{0},A_{0},R_{1}~{}~{},~{}~{}S_{1},A_{1},R_{2}~{}~{},~{}~{}S_{2},A_{2},R_{3}~% {}~{},...italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , …

    The set of rewards, actions and states will be respectively written as ℛ,𝒜ℛ𝒜\mathcal{R},\mathcal{A}caligraphic_R , caligraphic_A and 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S}caligraphic_S. We’ll also call 𝒜⁢(s)𝒜𝑠\mathcal{A}(s)caligraphic_A ( italic_s ) the actions which are feasible in a specific state St=ssubscript𝑆𝑡𝑠S_{t}=sitalic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_s.

    The Figure 3.1 shows schematically all the above concepts and how they are related.

  2. 2.

    Model of the environment
    Let us now suppose that we are able to have access to all the dynamic of our environment. Then, we can generally define a function which gives the probability of transiting in a certain state Stsubscript𝑆𝑡S_{t}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and receive a certain reward Rtsubscript𝑅𝑡R_{t}italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT if we were previously in the state St−1subscript𝑆𝑡1S_{t-1}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and made the action At−1subscript𝐴𝑡1A_{t-1}italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. That kind of function, defined for the whole action and state spaces is called the model of the environment. It can be generally defined as follows :

    p⁢(s′,r|s,a)≡P⁢r⁢({St=s′,Rt=r|St−1=s,At−1=a})⁢∀s,s′∈𝒮,r∈ℛ;a∈𝒜⁢(s)formulae-sequence𝑝superscript𝑠′conditional𝑟𝑠𝑎𝑃𝑟conditional-setformulae-sequencesubscript𝑆𝑡superscript𝑠′subscript𝑅𝑡𝑟formulae-sequencesubscript𝑆𝑡1𝑠subscript𝐴𝑡1𝑎for-all𝑠formulae-sequencesuperscript𝑠′𝒮formulae-sequence𝑟ℛ𝑎𝒜𝑠p(s^{\prime},r|s,a)\equiv Pr\Big{(}\{S_{t}=s^{\prime},R_{t}=r|S_{t-1}=s,A_{t-1% }=a\}\Big{)}~{}\forall s,s^{\prime}\in\mathcal{S}~{},r\in\mathcal{R};~{}a\in% \mathcal{A}(s)italic_p ( italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_r | italic_s , italic_a ) ≡ italic_P italic_r ( { italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_r | italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_s , italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_a } ) ∀ italic_s , italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∈ caligraphic_S , italic_r ∈ caligraphic_R ; italic_a ∈ caligraphic_A ( italic_s ) (3.1.4)

    Most of the time, it is assumed that, the next values depend only on the immediate previous values (Markov property) [22]. The Markov Property can be formalized as follows :

    p⁢(s′,r|s,a)=P⁢r⁢({St,Rt|St−1,At−1,St−2,At−2,…})=P⁢r⁢({St=s′,Rt=r|St−1=s,At−1=a})𝑝superscript𝑠′conditional𝑟𝑠𝑎𝑃𝑟conditional-setsubscript𝑆𝑡subscript𝑅𝑡subscript𝑆𝑡1subscript𝐴𝑡1subscript𝑆𝑡2subscript𝐴𝑡2…𝑃𝑟conditional-setformulae-sequencesubscript𝑆𝑡superscript𝑠′subscript𝑅𝑡𝑟formulae-sequencesubscript𝑆𝑡1𝑠subscript𝐴𝑡1𝑎p(s^{\prime},r|s,a)=Pr\Big{(}\{S_{t},R_{t}|S_{t-1},A_{t-1},S_{t-2},A_{t-2},...% \}\Big{)}=Pr\Big{(}\{S_{t}=s^{\prime},R_{t}=r|S_{t-1}=s,A_{t-1}=a\}\Big{)}italic_p ( italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_r | italic_s , italic_a ) = italic_P italic_r ( { italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t - 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t - 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … } ) = italic_P italic_r ( { italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_r | italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_s , italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_a } )

    This function defines the dynamic of a Markov decision process.

  3. 3.

    Other important definitions from the model of the environment
    MDPs are powerful tools for modeling and solving problems where decision making involves uncertainty and sequential actions. We are here giving other formal definitions which shows how we can derive well-known concepts from the general Definition given by the Expression 3.1.4 [36].

    1. (a)

      Second form of the environment model
      This definition is the commonly used but is not as general as the one we gave in Relation 3.1.4. The reward is not explicitly considered :

      p⁢(s′|s,a)≡P⁢r⁢{St=s′|St−1=s,At−1=a}=∑r∈ℛp⁢(s′,r|s,a)𝑝conditionalsuperscript𝑠′𝑠𝑎𝑃𝑟conditional-setsubscript𝑆𝑡superscript𝑠′formulae-sequencesubscript𝑆𝑡1𝑠subscript𝐴𝑡1𝑎subscript𝑟ℛ𝑝superscript𝑠′conditional𝑟𝑠𝑎p(s^{\prime}|s,a)\equiv Pr\left\{S_{t}=s^{\prime}|S_{t-1}=s,A_{t-1}=a\right\}=% \sum_{r\in\mathcal{R}}p(s^{\prime},r|s,a)italic_p ( italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | italic_s , italic_a ) ≡ italic_P italic_r { italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_s , italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_a } = ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_r ∈ caligraphic_R end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p ( italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_r | italic_s , italic_a ) (3.1.5)
    2. (b)

      Definition of the reward
      Here we define the reward without considering the next state of the environment:

      r⁢(s,a)≡𝔼⁢[Rt|St−1=s,At−1=a]=∑r∈ℛ(r⋅∑s′∈𝒮p⁢(s′,r|s,a))𝑟𝑠𝑎𝔼delimited-[]formulae-sequenceconditionalsubscript𝑅𝑡subscript𝑆𝑡1𝑠subscript𝐴𝑡1𝑎subscript𝑟ℛ⋅𝑟subscriptsuperscript𝑠′𝒮𝑝superscript𝑠′conditional𝑟𝑠𝑎r(s,a)\equiv\mathbb{E}\left[R_{t}|S_{t-1}=s,A_{t-1}=a\right]=\sum_{r\in% \mathcal{R}}\left(r\cdot\sum_{s^{\prime}\in\mathcal{S}}p(s^{\prime},r|s,a)\right)italic_r ( italic_s , italic_a ) ≡ blackboard_E [ italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_s , italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_a ] = ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_r ∈ caligraphic_R end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_r ⋅ ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∈ caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p ( italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_r | italic_s , italic_a ) ) (3.1.6)
    3. (c)

      Reward depending on next state
      Here we consider the next state in our definition of reward. That captures the most similar to our usual view of the reward function in real life:

      r⁢(s,a,s′)≡𝔼⁢[Rt|St−1=s,At−1=a,St=s′]=∑r∈ℛ(r⋅p⁢(s′,r|s,a)p⁢(s′|s,a))𝑟𝑠𝑎superscript𝑠′𝔼delimited-[]formulae-sequenceconditionalsubscript𝑅𝑡subscript𝑆𝑡1𝑠formulae-sequencesubscript𝐴𝑡1𝑎subscript𝑆𝑡superscript𝑠′subscript𝑟ℛ⋅𝑟𝑝superscript𝑠′conditional𝑟𝑠𝑎𝑝conditionalsuperscript𝑠′𝑠𝑎r(s,a,s^{\prime})\equiv\mathbb{E}\left[R_{t}|S_{t-1}=s,A_{t-1}=a,S_{t}=s^{% \prime}\right]=\sum_{r\in\mathcal{R}}\left(r\cdot\dfrac{p(s^{\prime},r|s,a)}{p% (s^{\prime}|s,a)}\right)italic_r ( italic_s , italic_a , italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ≡ blackboard_E [ italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_s , italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_a , italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] = ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_r ∈ caligraphic_R end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_r ⋅ divide start_ARG italic_p ( italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_r | italic_s , italic_a ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_p ( italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | italic_s , italic_a ) end_ARG ) (3.1.7)
  4. 4.

    Formalization of the concepts of goals, rewards and returns
    In Reinforcement Learning (RL), the purpose or goal of the agent is formalized in terms of a special signal called a “reward” as explained previously, which is sent to the agent from the environment. In other words, given the reward at any given time as just a real number, the “goal” of the agent is to maximize the total amount of rewards it receives. This is not a maximization of the immediate reward, but of the cumulative reward in the long run. With this in mind, if we call Rtsubscript𝑅𝑡R_{t}italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT the reward we get at time t𝑡titalic_t, we can generally define a function that we’ll call return at that time like this :

    Gt=Rt+1+γ⋅Rt+2+γ2⋅Rt+3+⋯=∑k=0∞γk⋅Rt+k+1⁢with⁢γ∈[0,1)subscript𝐺𝑡subscript𝑅𝑡1⋅𝛾subscript𝑅𝑡2⋅superscript𝛾2subscript𝑅𝑡3⋯superscriptsubscript𝑘0⋅superscript𝛾𝑘subscript𝑅𝑡𝑘1with𝛾01G_{t}=R_{t+1}+\gamma\cdot R_{t+2}+\gamma^{2}\cdot R_{t+3}+\cdots=\sum_{k=0}^{% \infty}\gamma^{k}\cdot R_{t+k+1}~{}~{}~{}\text{with}~{}~{}\gamma\in[0,1)italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_γ ⋅ italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t + 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_γ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⋅ italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t + 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + ⋯ = ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∞ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_γ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⋅ italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t + italic_k + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT with italic_γ ∈ [ 0 , 1 ) (3.1.8)

    In this Expression 3.1.8, the discount factor γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ can also be taken equal to one but this will lead to the divergence of the return function in infinite cases. This definition is mathematically consistent, and it is also consistent in real-life. In fact :

    • •

      Mathematically : Taking γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ in the interval [0,1)01[0,1)[ 0 , 1 ) ensures the convergence of the series if only the reward function is bounded.

    • •

      In real life : This definition of the return function is consistent with the concept that immediate rewards are more appreciated than rewards deferred into the future.

  5. 5.

    Policies and Value Functions
    Almost all RL algorithms involve estimating value functions, which are functions of states (or of state-action pairs) that estimate how good it is for an agent to be in a particular state (or to perform a particular action in a particular state).

    The reward that an agent can expect to receive in the future depends on which action will be taken. Accordingly, value functions are defined with respect to particular ways of acting, called policies. Formally, a policy is a mapping from states to action space. In general, it quantifies the probability of selecting a certain action in a specific state. So, the policy can be defined as follows:

    π⁢(a|s)≡π⁢(At=a|St=s)=P⁢r⁢{a∈𝒜⁢(s)|s},𝜋conditional𝑎𝑠𝜋subscript𝐴𝑡conditional𝑎subscript𝑆𝑡𝑠𝑃𝑟conditional-set𝑎𝒜𝑠𝑠\pi\left(a|s\right)\equiv\pi\left(A_{t}=a|S_{t}=s\right)=Pr\left\{a\in\mathcal% {A}(s)|s\right\},italic_π ( italic_a | italic_s ) ≡ italic_π ( italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_a | italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_s ) = italic_P italic_r { italic_a ∈ caligraphic_A ( italic_s ) | italic_s } , (3.1.9)

    where 𝒜⁢(s)𝒜𝑠\mathcal{A}(s)caligraphic_A ( italic_s ) represents the set of possible actions when we are in the state s𝑠sitalic_s.
    The value function now, for a state s𝑠sitalic_s, under a policy π𝜋\piitalic_π, denoted vπ⁢(s)subscript𝑣𝜋𝑠v_{\pi}(s)italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_π end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_s ), is the expected payoff of starting in that state and then following that policy. For MDPs we can formally say that the value function is given by :

    vπ⁢(s)≡𝔼π⁢[Gt|St=s]=𝔼π⁢[∑k=0∞γk⋅Rt+k+1|St=s]subscript𝑣𝜋𝑠subscript𝔼𝜋delimited-[]conditionalsubscript𝐺𝑡subscript𝑆𝑡𝑠subscript𝔼𝜋delimited-[]conditionalsuperscriptsubscript𝑘0⋅superscript𝛾𝑘subscript𝑅𝑡𝑘1subscript𝑆𝑡𝑠v_{\pi}(s)\equiv\mathbb{E}_{\pi}\left[G_{t}|S_{t}=s\right]=\mathbb{E}_{\pi}% \left[\sum_{k=0}^{\infty}\gamma^{k}\cdot R_{t+k+1}|S_{t}=s\right]italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_π end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_s ) ≡ blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_π end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_s ] = blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_π end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∞ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_γ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⋅ italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t + italic_k + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_s ] (3.1.10)

    We can similarly define the value function of taking an action a𝑎aitalic_a while following the same policy, starting in the state s𝑠sitalic_s, which is called the Q-value :
