    qπ⁢(s,a)≡𝔼π⁢[Gt|St=s,At=a]=𝔼π⁢[∑k=0∞γk⋅Rt+k+1|St=s,At=a]subscript𝑞𝜋𝑠𝑎subscript𝔼𝜋delimited-[]formulae-sequenceconditionalsubscript𝐺𝑡subscript𝑆𝑡𝑠subscript𝐴𝑡𝑎subscript𝔼𝜋delimited-[]formulae-sequenceconditionalsuperscriptsubscript𝑘0⋅superscript𝛾𝑘subscript𝑅𝑡𝑘1subscript𝑆𝑡𝑠subscript𝐴𝑡𝑎q_{\pi}(s,a)\equiv\mathbb{E}_{\pi}\left[G_{t}|S_{t}=s,A_{t}=a\right]=\mathbb{E% }_{\pi}\left[\sum_{k=0}^{\infty}\gamma^{k}\cdot R_{t+k+1}|S_{t}=s,A_{t}=a\right]italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_π end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_s , italic_a ) ≡ blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_π end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_s , italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_a ] = blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_π end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∞ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_γ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⋅ italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t + italic_k + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_s , italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_a ] (3.1.11)

    The equations 3.1.10 and 3.1.11 correspond respectively to the state-value function and the action-value function. Also, the state value function can be seen as the average of all the values that can be achieved by acting from a given state, i.e., we can see the state value function as a weighted average of the action-value functions that we can obtain starting from that state. So, formally :

    vπ⁢(s)≡∑a∈𝒜⁢(s)qπ⁢(s,a)⋅π⁢(a|s)subscript𝑣𝜋𝑠subscript𝑎𝒜𝑠⋅subscript𝑞𝜋𝑠𝑎𝜋conditional𝑎𝑠v_{\pi}(s)\equiv\sum_{a\in\mathcal{A}(s)}q_{\pi}(s,a)\cdot\pi(a|s)italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_π end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_s ) ≡ ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a ∈ caligraphic_A ( italic_s ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_π end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_s , italic_a ) ⋅ italic_π ( italic_a | italic_s ) (3.1.12)

    Now the following holds between the value of s𝑠sitalic_s and the value of its possible successor states for any policy π𝜋\piitalic_π and any state s𝑠sitalic_s :

    vπ⁢(s)subscript𝑣𝜋𝑠\displaystyle v_{\pi}(s)italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_π end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_s ) =𝔼π⁢[Gt|St=s]absentsubscript𝔼𝜋delimited-[]conditionalsubscript𝐺𝑡subscript𝑆𝑡𝑠\displaystyle=\mathbb{E}_{\pi}\left[G_{t}|S_{t}=s\right]= blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_π end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_s ]
    =𝔼π⁢[Rt+1+γ⋅Gt+1|St=s]absentsubscript𝔼𝜋delimited-[]subscript𝑅𝑡1conditional⋅𝛾subscript𝐺𝑡1subscript𝑆𝑡𝑠\displaystyle=\mathbb{E}_{\pi}\left[R_{t+1}+\gamma\cdot G_{t+1}|S_{t}=s\right]= blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_π end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_γ ⋅ italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_s ]
    =∑aπ⁢(a|s)⁢(∑s′∑rp⁢(s′,r|s,a)⁢[r+γ⋅𝔼π⁢[Gt+1|St+1=s′]])absentsubscript𝑎𝜋conditional𝑎𝑠subscriptsuperscript𝑠′subscript𝑟𝑝superscript𝑠′conditional𝑟𝑠𝑎delimited-[]𝑟⋅𝛾subscript𝔼𝜋delimited-[]conditionalsubscript𝐺𝑡1subscript𝑆𝑡1superscript𝑠′\displaystyle=\sum_{a}\pi(a|s)\left(\sum_{s^{\prime}}\sum_{r}p(s^{\prime},r|s,% a)\Big{[}r+\gamma\cdot\mathbb{E}_{\pi}\left[G_{t+1}|S_{t+1}=s^{\prime}\right]% \Big{]}\right)= ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_π ( italic_a | italic_s ) ( ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_r end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p ( italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_r | italic_s , italic_a ) [ italic_r + italic_γ ⋅ blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_π end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] ] ) (3.1.13)
    ⇒vπ⁢(s)⇒absentsubscript𝑣𝜋𝑠\displaystyle\Rightarrow v_{\pi}(s)⇒ italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_π end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_s ) =∑aπ⁢(a|s)⁢(∑s′,rp⁢(s′,r|s,a)⁢[r+γ⋅vπ⁢(s′)])absentsubscript𝑎𝜋conditional𝑎𝑠subscriptsuperscript𝑠′𝑟𝑝superscript𝑠′conditional𝑟𝑠𝑎delimited-[]𝑟⋅𝛾subscript𝑣𝜋superscript𝑠′\displaystyle=\sum_{a}\pi(a|s)\left(\sum_{s^{\prime},r}p(s^{\prime},r|s,a)\Big% {[}r+\gamma\cdot v_{\pi}(s^{\prime})\Big{]}\right)= ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_π ( italic_a | italic_s ) ( ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_r end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p ( italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_r | italic_s , italic_a ) [ italic_r + italic_γ ⋅ italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_π end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ] ) (3.1.14)
    using then the equation 3.1.6
    ⇒vπ⁢(s)⇒absentsubscript𝑣𝜋𝑠\displaystyle\Rightarrow v_{\pi}(s)⇒ italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_π end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_s ) =∑aπ⁢(a|s)⋅(r⁢(s,a)+γ⋅∑s′p⁢(s′|s,a)⁢vπ⁢(s′))absentsubscript𝑎⋅𝜋conditional𝑎𝑠𝑟𝑠𝑎⋅𝛾subscriptsuperscript𝑠′𝑝conditionalsuperscript𝑠′𝑠𝑎subscript𝑣𝜋superscript𝑠′\displaystyle=\sum_{a}\pi(a|s)\cdot\left(r(s,a)+\gamma\cdot\sum_{s^{\prime}}p(% s^{\prime}|s,a)v_{\pi}(s^{\prime})\right)= ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_π ( italic_a | italic_s ) ⋅ ( italic_r ( italic_s , italic_a ) + italic_γ ⋅ ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p ( italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | italic_s , italic_a ) italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_π end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ) (3.1.15)

    The Relation 3.1.13 is explained by the definition of the reward function given by the equation 3.1.6, and also by the fact that we normally have to do a weighted summation under the action set 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A}caligraphic_A to account for all actions. The equation 3.1.15 is then called Bellman equation for the value function vπsubscript𝑣𝜋v_{\pi}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_π end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.
    We can define in the same way the Bellman equation corresponding to the action-value function as follows [18] :

    qπ⁢(s,a)=r⁢(s,a)+γ⋅∑s′p⁢(s′|s,a)⋅(∑a′π⁢(a′|s′)⋅qπ⁢(s′,a′))subscript𝑞𝜋𝑠𝑎𝑟𝑠𝑎⋅𝛾subscriptsuperscript𝑠′⋅𝑝conditionalsuperscript𝑠′𝑠𝑎subscriptsuperscript𝑎′⋅𝜋conditionalsuperscript𝑎′superscript𝑠′subscript𝑞𝜋superscript𝑠′superscript𝑎′q_{\pi}(s,a)=r(s,a)+\gamma\cdot\sum_{s^{\prime}}p(s^{\prime}|s,a)\cdot\left(% \sum_{a^{\prime}}\pi(a^{\prime}|s^{\prime})\cdot q_{\pi}(s^{\prime},a^{\prime}% )\right)italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_π end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_s , italic_a ) = italic_r ( italic_s , italic_a ) + italic_γ ⋅ ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p ( italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | italic_s , italic_a ) ⋅ ( ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_π ( italic_a start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ⋅ italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_π end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_a start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ) (3.1.16)

From now on we can notice that the MDP framework is a considerable abstraction of the problem of goal-directed learning from interaction.

3.2 Optimal Policies and Optimal Value Functions

Here we present the optimal value functions and discuss how they can be used to find the optimal policy [36]. In fact, the value function defines a partial ordering over policies. More precisely, given two policies π𝜋\piitalic_π and π′superscript𝜋′\pi^{\prime}italic_π start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, we can say,

π≥π′⇔vπ⁢(s)≥vπ′⁢(s)∀s∈𝒮,iff𝜋superscript𝜋′formulae-sequencesubscript𝑣𝜋𝑠subscript𝑣superscript𝜋′𝑠for-all𝑠𝒮\pi\geq\pi^{\prime}\iff v_{\pi}(s)\geq v_{\pi^{\prime}}(s)~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}% \forall s\in\mathcal{S},italic_π ≥ italic_π start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⇔ italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_π end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_s ) ≥ italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_π start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_s ) ∀ italic_s ∈ caligraphic_S , (3.2.1)

but we are not always able to compare two value functions. So, the policy π𝜋\piitalic_π is defined to be better than or equal to π′superscript𝜋′\pi^{\prime}italic_π start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT if its expected return is greater than or equal to that of π′superscript𝜋′\pi^{\prime}italic_π start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT for all states.
And now, if π∗superscript𝜋\pi^{*}italic_π start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is the optimal policy we have :

{v∗⁢(s)≡max𝜋⁢vπ⁢(s)q∗⁢(s,a)≡max𝜋⁢qπ⁢(s,a)=𝔼⁢[Rt+1+γ⋅v∗⁢(St+1)|St=s,At=a]casessubscript𝑣𝑠𝜋subscript𝑣𝜋𝑠subscript𝑞𝑠𝑎𝜋subscript𝑞𝜋𝑠𝑎𝔼delimited-[]formulae-sequencesubscript𝑅𝑡1conditional⋅𝛾subscript𝑣subscript𝑆𝑡1subscript𝑆𝑡𝑠subscript𝐴𝑡𝑎\displaystyle\left\{\begin{array}[]{lcl}v_{*}(s)&\equiv&\underset{\pi}{\max}~{% }v_{\pi}(s)\\ q_{*}(s,a)&\equiv&\underset{\pi}{\max}~{}q_{\pi}(s,a)=\mathbb{E}\left[R_{t+1}+% \gamma\cdot v_{*}(S_{t+1})|S_{t}=s,A_{t}=a\right]\end{array}\right.{ start_ARRAY start_ROW start_CELL italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_s ) end_CELL start_CELL ≡ end_CELL start_CELL underitalic_π start_ARG roman_max end_ARG italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_π end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_s ) end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_s , italic_a ) end_CELL start_CELL ≡ end_CELL start_CELL underitalic_π start_ARG roman_max end_ARG italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_π end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_s , italic_a ) = blackboard_E [ italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_γ ⋅ italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) | italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_s , italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_a ] end_CELL end_ROW end_ARRAY (3.2.4)

3.2.1 Bellman optimality equation

Since we take the optimal action at each time (following the optimal policy π∗superscript𝜋\pi^{*}italic_π start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT), we can write v∗⁢(s)=maxa∈𝒜⁢(s)⁢qπ∗⁢(s,a)subscript𝑣𝑠𝑎𝒜𝑠subscript𝑞superscript𝜋𝑠𝑎v_{*}(s)=\underset{a\in\mathcal{A}(s)}{\max}~{}q_{\pi^{*}}(s,a)italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_s ) = start_UNDERACCENT italic_a ∈ caligraphic_A ( italic_s ) end_UNDERACCENT start_ARG roman_max end_ARG italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_π start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_s , italic_a ) , and this will be the best achievable expected reward at each time. So :

v∗⁢(s)subscript𝑣𝑠\displaystyle v_{*}(s)italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_s ) =maxa∈𝒜⁢(s)⁢qπ∗⁢(s,a)absent𝑎𝒜𝑠subscript𝑞superscript𝜋𝑠𝑎\displaystyle=\underset{a\in\mathcal{A}(s)}{\max}~{}q_{\pi^{*}}(s,a)= start_UNDERACCENT italic_a ∈ caligraphic_A ( italic_s ) end_UNDERACCENT start_ARG roman_max end_ARG italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_π start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_s , italic_a )
=max𝑎⁢𝔼π∗⁢[Gt|St=s,At=a]absent𝑎subscript𝔼superscript𝜋delimited-[]formulae-sequenceconditionalsubscript𝐺𝑡subscript𝑆𝑡𝑠subscript𝐴𝑡𝑎\displaystyle=\underset{a}{\max}~{}\mathbb{E}_{\pi^{*}}\left[G_{t}|S_{t}=s,A_{% t}=a\right]= underitalic_a start_ARG roman_max end_ARG blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_π start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_s , italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_a ]
=max𝑎⁢𝔼π∗⁢[Rt+1+γ⋅Gt+1|St=s,At=a]absent𝑎subscript𝔼superscript𝜋delimited-[]formulae-sequencesubscript𝑅𝑡1conditional⋅𝛾subscript𝐺𝑡1subscript𝑆𝑡𝑠subscript𝐴𝑡𝑎\displaystyle=\underset{a}{\max}~{}\mathbb{E}_{\pi^{*}}\left[R_{t+1}+\gamma% \cdot G_{t+1}|S_{t}=s,A_{t}=a\right]= underitalic_a start_ARG roman_max end_ARG blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_π start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_γ ⋅ italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_s , italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_a ]
=max𝑎⁢𝔼π∗⁢[Rt+1+γ⋅v∗⁢(St+1)|St=s,At=a]absent𝑎subscript𝔼superscript𝜋delimited-[]formulae-sequencesubscript𝑅𝑡1conditional⋅𝛾subscript𝑣subscript𝑆𝑡1subscript𝑆𝑡𝑠subscript𝐴𝑡𝑎\displaystyle=\underset{a}{\max}~{}\mathbb{E}_{\pi^{*}}\left[R_{t+1}+\gamma% \cdot v_{*}(S_{t+1})|S_{t}=s,A_{t}=a\right]= underitalic_a start_ARG roman_max end_ARG blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_π start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_γ ⋅ italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) | italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_s , italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_a ]
=max𝑎⁢∑s′,rp⁢(s′,r|s,a)⋅[r+γ⋅v∗⁢(s′)]absent𝑎subscriptsuperscript𝑠′𝑟⋅𝑝superscript𝑠′conditional𝑟𝑠𝑎delimited-[]𝑟⋅𝛾subscript𝑣superscript𝑠′\displaystyle=\underset{a}{\max}~{}\sum_{s^{\prime},r}p(s^{\prime},r|s,a)\cdot% \left[r+\gamma\cdot v_{*}(s^{\prime})\right]= underitalic_a start_ARG roman_max end_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_r end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p ( italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_r | italic_s , italic_a ) ⋅ [ italic_r + italic_γ ⋅ italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ]
=max𝑎⁢[r⁢(s,a)+γ⋅∑s′p⁢(s′|s,a)⁢v∗⁢(s′)]absent𝑎delimited-[]𝑟𝑠𝑎⋅𝛾subscriptsuperscript𝑠′𝑝conditionalsuperscript𝑠′𝑠𝑎subscript𝑣superscript𝑠′\displaystyle=\underset{a}{\max}\left[r(s,a)+\gamma\cdot\sum_{s^{\prime}}p(s^{% \prime}|s,a)v_{*}(s^{\prime})\right]= underitalic_a start_ARG roman_max end_ARG [ italic_r ( italic_s , italic_a ) + italic_γ ⋅ ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p ( italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | italic_s , italic_a ) italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ] (3.2.5)

The Expression (3.2.5) follows the definition of the model of the environment given in point 2 on page 2. We can then show the consistency with the connection given in Expression (3.1.12) by deducing q∗⁢(s,a)subscript𝑞𝑠𝑎q_{*}(s,a)italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_s , italic_a ) as follows :

q∗⁢(s,a)subscript𝑞𝑠𝑎\displaystyle q_{*}(s,a)italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_s , italic_a ) =𝔼⁢[Rt+1+γ⋅maxa′⁢q∗⁢(s′,a′)|St=s,At=a,St+1=s′,At+1=a′]absent𝔼delimited-[]formulae-sequencesubscript𝑅𝑡1conditional⋅𝛾superscript𝑎′subscript𝑞superscript𝑠′superscript𝑎′subscript𝑆𝑡𝑠formulae-sequencesubscript𝐴𝑡𝑎formulae-sequencesubscript𝑆𝑡1superscript𝑠′subscript𝐴𝑡1superscript𝑎′\displaystyle=\mathbb{E}\left[R_{t+1}+\gamma\cdot\underset{a^{\prime}}{\max}~{% }q_{*}(s^{\prime},a^{\prime})|S_{t}=s,A_{t}=a,~{}~{}S_{t+1}=s^{\prime},A_{t+1}% =a^{\prime}\right]= blackboard_E [ italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_γ ⋅ start_UNDERACCENT italic_a start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_UNDERACCENT start_ARG roman_max end_ARG italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_a start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) | italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_s , italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_a , italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_a start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ]
=∑s′,rp⁢(s′,r|s,a)⋅[r+γ⋅maxa′⁢q∗⁢(s′,a′)]absentsubscriptsuperscript𝑠′𝑟⋅𝑝superscript𝑠′conditional𝑟𝑠𝑎delimited-[]𝑟⋅𝛾superscript𝑎′subscript𝑞superscript𝑠′superscript𝑎′\displaystyle=\sum_{s^{\prime},r}p(s^{\prime},r|s,a)\cdot\left[r+\gamma\cdot% \underset{a^{\prime}}{\max}~{}{q_{*}(s^{\prime},a^{\prime})}\right]= ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_r end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p ( italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_r | italic_s , italic_a ) ⋅ [ italic_r + italic_γ ⋅ start_UNDERACCENT italic_a start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_UNDERACCENT start_ARG roman_max end_ARG italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_a start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ]
⇒q∗⁢(s,a)⇒absentsubscript𝑞𝑠𝑎\displaystyle\Rightarrow q_{*}(s,a)⇒ italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_s , italic_a ) =r⁢(s,a)+γ⋅∑s′p⁢(s′|s,a)⋅maxa′⁢q∗⁢(s′,a′)absent𝑟𝑠𝑎⋅𝛾subscriptsuperscript𝑠′⋅𝑝conditionalsuperscript𝑠′𝑠𝑎superscript𝑎′subscript𝑞superscript𝑠′superscript𝑎′\displaystyle=r(s,a)+\gamma\cdot\sum_{s^{\prime}}p(s^{\prime}|s,a)\cdot% \underset{a^{\prime}}{\max}~{}{q_{*}(s^{\prime},a^{\prime})}= italic_r ( italic_s , italic_a ) + italic_γ ⋅ ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p ( italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | italic_s , italic_a ) ⋅ start_UNDERACCENT italic_a start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_UNDERACCENT start_ARG roman_max end_ARG italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_a start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT )
⇒q∗⁢(s,a)⇒absentsubscript𝑞𝑠𝑎\displaystyle\Rightarrow q_{*}(s,a)⇒ italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_s , italic_a ) =r⁢(s,a)+γ⋅∑s′p⁢(s′|s,a)⋅v∗⁢(s′)absent𝑟𝑠𝑎⋅𝛾subscriptsuperscript𝑠′⋅𝑝conditionalsuperscript𝑠′𝑠𝑎subscript𝑣superscript𝑠′\displaystyle=r(s,a)+\gamma\cdot\sum_{s^{\prime}}p(s^{\prime}|s,a)\cdot{v_{*}(% s^{\prime})}= italic_r ( italic_s , italic_a ) + italic_γ ⋅ ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p ( italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | italic_s , italic_a ) ⋅ italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) (3.2.6)

Equations (3.2.5) and (3.2.6) are called Bellman optimality equations. For a finite MDP, the Bellman optimality equation has a unique solution (in the case of infinite MDPs, the Bellman optimality equation may not have a unique solution because infinite MDPs can have multiple optimal policies that lead to the same value function).
And having the optimal value function v∗subscript𝑣v_{*}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, one can determine an optimal policy (because the value function defines a partial order on the policy space).

Finally, even if we have a complete and accurate model of the environment (the dynamics), it is usually not possible to compute an optimal policy simply by solving the Bellman equation. Therefore, approximate methods are developed and used [33].

3.3 Solving Markov Decision Processes

Solving an MDP means try to find an optimal value function v∗subscript𝑣v_{*}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT or q∗subscript𝑞q_{*}italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, which corresponds to find the optimal policy π∗superscript𝜋\pi^{*}italic_π start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.
There are many ways of doing that, and algorithms were developed for specific challenges. The most used classification consists in distinguishing model-based and model-free algorithms, direct or indirect.
Generally, model-based algorithms concern what is called Dynamic Programming (DP). Model-based algorithms assume that the model of the environment is well known and can be used to find value functions and policies using the Bellman equations.
Model-free algorithms now, is considered as true-RL algorithms. They don’t require the availability of a perfect model (we suppose that, the environment is not totally known). This method rely on interaction with the environment. That interaction is done by simulating the policy and generating samples of state transitions and rewards. Then, the samples are used to estimate value functions and even to improve the used policy.
In model-free algorithms, since no model of the MDP is known, the agent must explore the MDP to obtain information. This introduces a exploration-exploitation trade-off that must be balanced to obtain an optimal policy.
We can also talk about model-based reinforcement learning algorithms in which the agent does not possess, at the beginning, a model of the environment, but estimates it after a certain amount of time. Once a reasonable model of the environment has been induced, the agent can then apply dynamic programming algorithms to compute the optimal policy.

3.3.1 Dynamic Programming based algorithms or Model-based algorithms

Taking a complex problem, breaking it down into simpler components and solving them recursively is the main idea of dynamic programming.
There are two main Dynamic Programming algorithms from which we can derive others. Policy iteration [17] and value iteration [9]. These two algorithms are based on two principal concepts (policy evaluation and policy improvement) below explained :

  1. 1.

    Policy evaluation :
    The partial order defined by the Relation 3.2.1 gives a way of comparing two policies. Now, by establishing an order between value functions, we can find the best policy. But before doing that, we have to evaluate each specific policy.
    Policy evaluation consists on finding the value function using the function vπsubscript𝑣𝜋v_{\pi}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_π end_POSTSUBSCRIPT defined in Relation 3.1.15 iteratively until convergence. This is done using the following discrete version of the value function :

    vπk+1⁢(s)⟵∑aπ⁢(a|s)⋅(r⁢(s,a)+γ⋅∑s′p⁢(s′|s,a)⋅vπk⁢(s′))⟵superscriptsubscript𝑣𝜋𝑘1𝑠subscript𝑎⋅𝜋conditional𝑎𝑠𝑟𝑠𝑎⋅𝛾subscriptsuperscript𝑠′⋅𝑝conditionalsuperscript𝑠′𝑠𝑎subscriptsuperscript𝑣𝑘𝜋superscript𝑠′v_{\pi}^{k+1}(s)\longleftarrow\sum_{a}\pi(a|s)\cdot\left(r(s,a)+\gamma\cdot% \sum_{s^{\prime}}p(s^{\prime}|s,a)\cdot v^{k}_{\pi}(s^{\prime})\right)italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_π end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_s ) ⟵ ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_π ( italic_a | italic_s ) ⋅ ( italic_r ( italic_s , italic_a ) + italic_γ ⋅ ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p ( italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | italic_s , italic_a ) ⋅ italic_v start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_π end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ) (3.3.1)

    The algorithm 1 below describes how the values of each state are computed iteratively to evaluate the policy [18] :

  2. 2.

    Policy improvement :
    In RL, the final goal is to find the optimal policy. Since the policy space is very huge, the task becomes infeasible. This is why, the policy improvement algorithm, as a solution to that problem, aim to find iteratively the optimal policy, by making small improvements on the current one.
    The idea is to modify the current policy greedily with respect to the value function. But, here we should definitely use the action-value function instead of the state one because the policy is about choosing an action. This will result in a deterministic policy (i.e. the probabilities for each case are 00 or 1111). The only remaining problem is to compute at each time the action-value function but we don’t have an estimate of it. Fortunately, as we have already a way to get iteratively the state-value function (using policy evaluation), we can now use it in the expression of the action-value function.
    Knowing the relation between q𝑞qitalic_q and v𝑣vitalic_v, (Relation 3.1.12), we can modify the Expression 3.1.16 as follows :

    qπ⁢(s,a)=r⁢(s,a)+γ⋅∑s′p⁢(s′|s,a)⋅vπ⁢(s′)subscript𝑞𝜋𝑠𝑎𝑟𝑠𝑎⋅𝛾subscriptsuperscript𝑠′⋅𝑝conditionalsuperscript𝑠′𝑠𝑎subscript𝑣𝜋superscript𝑠′q_{\pi}(s,a)=r(s,a)+\gamma\cdot\sum_{s^{\prime}}p(s^{\prime}|s,a)\cdot v_{\pi}% (s^{\prime})italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_π end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_s , italic_a ) = italic_r ( italic_s , italic_a ) + italic_γ ⋅ ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p ( italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | italic_s , italic_a ) ⋅ italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_π end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) (3.3.2)

    So, the algorithm 2 below gives with more details how to improve gradually the policy [18] :

    Now we can look easily on the value iteration and the policy iteration, which are our goals for these Dynamic Programming techniques of solving Markov Decision Processes.

  1. 1.

    Policy iteration :
    Policy iteration is used to find the optimal policy in a Markov decision process (MDP). This algorithm consists of two main steps, policy evaluation and policy improvement. Those two steps are iteratively applied to refine the policy until it converges to the optimal one.

  2. 2.

    Value iteration :
    This value iteration algorithm is like an improvement of policy iteration. In fact, the latter algorithm works effectively and find the optimal policy but it can take a lot of time because at each epoch it computes the policy evaluation and the policy improvement. Value iteration combines policy evaluation and policy improvement into one step. The idea is to replace the general expression of the value function for a given policy (Expression 3.1.15) by the one giving the optimal value function (Expression 3.2.5) in the Expression 3.3.2.

Generally, DP algorithms provide a powerful framework for solving reinforcement learning problems when a perfect model of the environment is known. It decomposes the problem into simpler subproblems and then uses the Bellman equations to compute the value functions. Optimality is reached when the expected cumulative reward is maximised.
Unfortunately, the model of the environment is not always available. Also, DP algorithms can be computationally expensive, especially for problems with large state and action spaces. For those reasons, other RL methods have been developed, such as Monte Carlo methods and temporal difference learning [35].

3.3.2 Model-free algorithms : Monte Carlo

Dynamic Programming (DP) assumes that the agent has a perfect access to the model of the environment (dynamics of the environment). But most of the time, we don’t have access to that. Additionally, sometimes the state and/or action spaces are very huge in such a way that DP algorithm can be inefficient.
Monte Carlo refers to the method of using experience to estimate value functions by averaging sample returns. Statistically it is proven to converge to the true estimate of the returns [10]. It uses sequences of state-action-reward samples generated by the agent by interacting with the environment.
There are always two important steps to be taken into account, the evaluation step and the improvement step. The idea of Monte Carlo (MC) policy evaluation for example is, following a certain policy π𝜋\piitalic_π, to generate a sample of state-action-reward-state or state-action-reward-state-action starting from a certain state. After generating a large amount for many episodes (because here we are talking about processes which have a terminating state, i.e. they can end in a finite number of steps), the expected return is obtained by averaging the returns from a large amount of complete sample episodes. This gives the corresponding value for that state, given that specific policy. As the number increases, the average will converges to the true value of vπsubscript𝑣𝜋v_{\pi}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_π end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [10].
The previous text just gives a general idea on how MC works. But, there are many implementations of this idea :

  • •

    First-visit MC policy evaluation (using value function or action-value function)

  • •

    Every-visit MC policy evaluation (using value function or action-value function)

  • •

    Incremental MC policy evaluation (using value function or action-value function)

  • •

    Monte Carlo Control (Monte Carlo Policy Improvement).

Here is a succinct presentation of those main MC approaches :

  1. 1.

    First-visit Monte Carlo Policy Evaluation
    The idea of this method is to generate a lots of samples, compute the returns at each step within each episode and update the estimate of the state value function for each state (at the end of the considered episode). The update is done by observing whether it is the first time to visit the state in each episode and then update the return and the number of visits. At the end, the expected return will be the average of the returns. What we have just explained is summarised in the following algorithm [18] :

  2. 2.

    Every-visit Monte Carlo Policy Evaluation
    A visit to a state s𝑠sitalic_s is each time the agent passes to that specific state. In the first-visit algorithm, only the first time is considered in each episode while updating the return. For the every-visit, all the visits, even within an episode are taken into account. The former method is unbiased but has an higher variance, the latter is biased with a lower variance. The trade-off is now taken by considering that aspect. Sometime even a combination of them is envisioned. The algorithm comes from a small modification on the one for first-visit [18, 36].

  3. 3.

    Incremental Monte Carlo Policy Evaluation
    The update method used line 11 of the previous algorithm 3 is still perfectible. In fact, many researches have shown that the incremental updates converges better than the simple update as done in the previous algorithm [18]. So, instead of vπ⁢(St)⟵G⁢(St)/N⁢(St)⟵subscript𝑣𝜋subscript𝑆𝑡𝐺subscript𝑆𝑡𝑁subscript𝑆𝑡v_{\pi}(S_{t})\longleftarrow G(S_{t})/N(S_{t})italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_π end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ⟵ italic_G ( italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) / italic_N ( italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), the incremental approach consists on doing :

    vπ⁢(St)⟵vπ⁢(St)+1N⁢(St)⋅(G⁢(St)−vπ⁢(St))⏟incremental error⟵subscript𝑣𝜋subscript𝑆𝑡subscript𝑣𝜋subscript𝑆𝑡⋅1𝑁subscript𝑆𝑡incremental error⏟𝐺subscript𝑆𝑡subscript𝑣𝜋subscript𝑆𝑡v_{\pi}(S_{t})\longleftarrow v_{\pi}(S_{t})+\dfrac{1}{N(S_{t})}\cdot\underset{% \text{incremental error}}{\underbrace{\left(G(S_{t})-v_{\pi}(S_{t})\right)}}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_π end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ⟵ italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_π end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) + divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_N ( italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG ⋅ underincremental error start_ARG under⏟ start_ARG ( italic_G ( italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_π end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) end_ARG end_ARG (3.3.3)

All these algorithms, can also be used by considering the action-value function instead of the state value function. We just have to change mutatus mutandi everything. For example, for the incremental update shown in Relation 3.3.3, we simply do :

qπ⁢(St,At)⟵qπ⁢(St,At)+1N⁢(St,At)⋅(Gt−qπ⁢(St,At))⟵subscript𝑞𝜋subscript𝑆𝑡subscript𝐴𝑡subscript𝑞𝜋subscript𝑆𝑡subscript𝐴𝑡⋅1𝑁subscript𝑆𝑡subscript𝐴𝑡subscript𝐺𝑡subscript𝑞𝜋subscript𝑆𝑡subscript𝐴𝑡q_{\pi}(S_{t},A_{t})\longleftarrow q_{\pi}(S_{t},A_{t})+\dfrac{1}{N(S_{t},A_{t% })}\cdot\Big{(}G_{t}-q_{\pi}(S_{t},A_{t})\Big{)}italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_π end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ⟵ italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_π end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) + divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_N ( italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG ⋅ ( italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_π end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) (3.3.4)

Also, exactly as for Dynamic Programming, the control step can be considered. The control step consists now on changing greedily the policy. For this case, there is for example Monte Carlo Control or Policy Improvement. For this, we can even try to do not always choose the best value but combine exploration and exploitation in a good way for better results [40].

3.3.3 Model-free algorithms : Temporal Difference

MC is limited to episodic problems. Temporal Difference (TD) methods generalize MC by dealing with both episodic and continuing (no natural ending or terminating state for the considered task) or infinite RL problems.
So, MC has two main drawbacks : it only takes into account episodic problems and we have to wait for the end of an episode to do any update on the estimated values. This is called Temporal Difference because the agent update its estimates based on the immediate reward and the estimated value for the next state without waiting for the end, even if these values will change another time during the episode. The main idea is a continuous updating of values, a guess from guesses.
Let’s give the most important implementations which really show how TD works :

  1. 1.

    TD Policy evaluation :
    For a given policy, samples are generated and at the same time incremental update is applied in the following way, without waiting for the end :

    vπ⁢(St)subscript𝑣𝜋subscript𝑆𝑡\displaystyle v_{\pi}(S_{t})italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_π end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ⟵vπ⁢(St)+λ⋅(Gt−vπ⁢(St))⟵absentsubscript𝑣𝜋subscript𝑆𝑡⋅𝜆subscript𝐺𝑡subscript𝑣𝜋subscript𝑆𝑡\displaystyle\longleftarrow v_{\pi}(S_{t})+\lambda\cdot\left(G_{t}-v_{\pi}(S_{% t})\right)⟵ italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_π end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) + italic_λ ⋅ ( italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_π end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) )
    ⟵vπ⁢(St)+λ⋅([Rt+γ⋅vπ⁢(St+1)]−vπ⁢(St))⟵absentsubscript𝑣𝜋subscript𝑆𝑡⋅𝜆delimited-[]subscript𝑅𝑡⋅𝛾subscript𝑣𝜋subscript𝑆𝑡1subscript𝑣𝜋subscript𝑆𝑡\displaystyle\longleftarrow v_{\pi}(S_{t})+\lambda\cdot\Big{(}\left[R_{t}+% \gamma\cdot v_{\pi}(S_{t+1})\right]-v_{\pi}(S_{t})\Big{)}⟵ italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_π end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) + italic_λ ⋅ ( [ italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_γ ⋅ italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_π end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ] - italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_π end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) (3.3.5)

    We here show the corresponding algorithm :

    If we need to work with action-value functions, we just have to replace vπsubscript𝑣𝜋v_{\pi}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_π end_POSTSUBSCRIPT by qπsubscript𝑞𝜋q_{\pi}italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_π end_POSTSUBSCRIPT coherently in equation 1. One obtains :

    qπ⁢(St,At)subscript𝑞𝜋subscript𝑆𝑡subscript𝐴𝑡\displaystyle q_{\pi}(S_{t},A_{t})italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_π end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ⟵qπ⁢(St,At)+λ⋅(Gt−qπ⁢(St,At))⟵absentsubscript𝑞𝜋subscript𝑆𝑡subscript𝐴𝑡⋅𝜆subscript𝐺𝑡subscript𝑞𝜋subscript𝑆𝑡subscript𝐴𝑡\displaystyle\longleftarrow q_{\pi}(S_{t},A_{t})+\lambda\cdot\left(G_{t}-q_{% \pi}(S_{t},A_{t})\right)⟵ italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_π end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) + italic_λ ⋅ ( italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_π end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) )
    ⟵qπ⁢(St,At)+λ⋅([Rt+γ⋅qπ⁢(St+1,At+1)]−qπ⁢(St,At))⟵absentsubscript𝑞𝜋subscript𝑆𝑡subscript𝐴𝑡⋅𝜆delimited-[]subscript𝑅𝑡⋅𝛾subscript𝑞𝜋subscript𝑆𝑡1subscript𝐴𝑡1subscript𝑞𝜋subscript𝑆𝑡subscript𝐴𝑡\displaystyle\longleftarrow q_{\pi}(S_{t},A_{t})+\lambda\cdot\Big{(}\left[R_{t% }+\gamma\cdot q_{\pi}(S_{t+1},A_{t+1})\right]-q_{\pi}(S_{t},A_{t})\Big{)}⟵ italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_π end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) + italic_λ ⋅ ( [ italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_γ ⋅ italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_π end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ] - italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_π end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) (3.3.6)

    At the end of the algorithm, we’ll update the state as well as the action in case we are using the Expression 1.
    Based on this idea, the update can go far than one step as in the Expression 1. In fact, we can replace Gt=Rt+γ⋅vπ⁢(St+1)subscript𝐺𝑡subscript𝑅𝑡⋅𝛾subscript𝑣𝜋subscript𝑆𝑡1G_{t}=R_{t}+\gamma\cdot v_{\pi}(S_{t+1})italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_γ ⋅ italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_π end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) by Gt=Rt+γ⋅Rt+1+⋯+γn⋅vπ⁢(St+n)subscript𝐺𝑡subscript𝑅𝑡⋅𝛾subscript𝑅𝑡1⋯⋅superscript𝛾𝑛subscript𝑣𝜋subscript𝑆𝑡𝑛G_{t}=R_{t}+\gamma\cdot R_{t+1}+\cdots+\gamma^{n}\cdot v_{\pi}(S_{t+n})italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_γ ⋅ italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + ⋯ + italic_γ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⋅ italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_π end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t + italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ). Depending on when we stop, it gives us different levels of bootstrapping. This generalizes the TD(0) algorithm we have been illustrating in this part. So, in general we have just an n-step TD Policy Evaluation that we choose to write TD(n) with n+1 the number of steps ahead in the formula [18, 36].

  2. 2.

    TD Control : SARSA
    SARSA stands literally for State-Action-Reward-State-Action. This method uses in fact the general policy iteration template that we have shown in the Dynamic Programming part to find the optimal policy. But it uses specific methods to manage exploration and exploitation while searching for the optimal policy. In fact, from the previous policy iteration that we saw in the DP part, we have to take at each time the one which gives the maximum return (exploitation). But for this case, we can sometimes take a suboptimal action (exploration) with a certain probability ε𝜀\varepsilonitalic_ε. This is what we call an ε⁢-greedy𝜀-greedy\varepsilon\text{-greedy}italic_ε -greedy selection method.
    Simply, the main idea is to loop on all the states for all the actions (state-action pairs) and then use an ε⁢-greedy𝜀-greedy\varepsilon\text{-greedy}italic_ε -greedy policy to select the best action. But note that there are many ways of managing the exploration-exploitation trade-off [18].
    In general also, we can use n-step TD Policy Evaluation in the evaluation part of this policy iteration. It now gives raise to all other implementations of SARSA n-step SARSA [36].

  3. 3.

    TD Control : Q-Learning
    The SARSA algorithm previously introduced is in fact a family of general policy iteration algorithm which estimates the state-action value function qπsubscript𝑞𝜋q_{\pi}italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_π end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for a policy π𝜋\piitalic_π and uses an ε⁢-greedy𝜀-greedy\varepsilon\text{-greedy}italic_ε -greedy policy to compute a new, better policy π′superscript𝜋′\pi^{\prime}italic_π start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. But, as we did for value iteration algorithm, we can skip the step of estimating values for a policy π𝜋\piitalic_π by directly making an estimation using the optimal value function formula, so that we’ll be directly estimating the optimal policy. For Q-Learning, we use the same idea by changing the Relation 1 by :

    q⁢(St,At)⟵q⁢(St,At)+λ⋅([Rt+γ⋅m⁢a⁢xa′⁢q⁢(St+1=s′,a′)]−q⁢(St,At))⟵𝑞subscript𝑆𝑡subscript𝐴𝑡𝑞subscript𝑆𝑡subscript𝐴𝑡⋅𝜆delimited-[]subscript𝑅𝑡⋅𝛾superscript𝑎′𝑚𝑎𝑥𝑞subscript𝑆𝑡1superscript𝑠′superscript𝑎′𝑞subscript𝑆𝑡subscript𝐴𝑡q(S_{t},A_{t})\longleftarrow q(S_{t},A_{t})+\lambda\cdot\left(\left[R_{t}+% \gamma\cdot\underset{a^{\prime}}{max}~{}q(S_{t+1}=s^{\prime},a^{\prime})\right% ]-q(S_{t},A_{t})\right)italic_q ( italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ⟵ italic_q ( italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) + italic_λ ⋅ ( [ italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_γ ⋅ start_UNDERACCENT italic_a start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_UNDERACCENT start_ARG italic_m italic_a italic_x end_ARG italic_q ( italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_a start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ] - italic_q ( italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) (3.3.7)

    One advantage of this algorithm is that it always uses the maximum value q⁢(St+1,a′)𝑞subscript𝑆𝑡1superscript𝑎′q(S_{t+1},a^{\prime})italic_q ( italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_a start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) across all valid actions for the successor state St+1=s′subscript𝑆𝑡1superscript𝑠′S_{t+1}=s^{\prime}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, regardless of which action is chosen by the policy.
    We should note that, even if Q-Learning is one of the most used in real-world problems, it may be biased. This is why another method called Double Q-Learning was suggested to alleviate that problem [36, 39].

In many of the tasks the state space is very huge. In such cases, even with the most efficient algorithms we have described above, we cannot expect to find an optimal policy or the optimal value function even in the limit of infinite time and data. Most of the time then, the goal is to find a good approximate of the function we are looking for. Using linear or non-linear approximates. For more information about that, see [18, 30, 36].

Now, as we have seen the main approaches to solve an MDP, which in fact resume the key points of RL foundational algorithms, we can now discuss on how it is related to the fixed point theory.

Chapter Conclusion

In this chapter, we have shown the fundamentals of Reinforcement Learning and how it is connected to Markov Decision Processes. After that, we have discussed about the optimal value functions and optimal policies and then at the end we have shown how generally the optimality is accomplished in RL. The next chapter will now formalize what we have just presented in this chapter as formula to find the optimal policy in terms of operators. This will now allow us to show the connection with the Banach Contraction Principle and how it can help understand deeply why and how RL algorithms work.

Chapter 4 Bellman Operators and Convergence of RL algorithms

In this chapter, we will express reinforcement in terms of operators so that we have a simple way to prove why reinforcement learning algorithms work well and find the optimal policy. To do this, we will first write the Banach contraction principle on normed spaces in a way that makes it easy to use in our next proofs, then we will discuss the Bellman operators, and finally we will talk about the core methods for finding optimality introduced in the previous chapter (but now using the language introduced in this chapter).

4.1 Refinement of the Banach Contraction Principle

We need to state the Banach Contraction Principle presented in the first chapter in such a way that everything in this part will be expressed in the same way, using the same language.

4.1.1 Contraction mapping and fixed-point

Let us now refine everything in term of norms in such a way that we will have a consistent notation until the end of this work. In fact, as we can see in this work, all the concepts related to reinforcement learning are defined in term of norms. So,

4.1.2 Definition.

Let (X,||⋅||)(X,||\cdot||)( italic_X , | | ⋅ | | ) be a normed space. A mapping 𝒯:X→X:𝒯→𝑋𝑋\mathcal{T}:X\rightarrow Xcaligraphic_T : italic_X → italic_X is a γ−limit-from𝛾\gamma-italic_γ -contraction mapping if, there exists a γ∈[0,1)𝛾01\gamma\in[0,1)italic_γ ∈ [ 0 , 1 ) such that, for any x1,x2∈Xsubscript𝑥1subscript𝑥2𝑋x_{1},x_{2}\in Xitalic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ italic_X we have

‖𝒯⁢x1−𝒯⁢x2‖≤γ⋅‖x1−x2‖norm𝒯subscript𝑥1𝒯subscript𝑥2⋅𝛾normsubscript𝑥1subscript𝑥2||\mathcal{T}x_{1}-\mathcal{T}x_{2}||\leq\gamma\cdot||x_{1}-x_{2}||| | caligraphic_T italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - caligraphic_T italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | | ≤ italic_γ ⋅ | | italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | |

From this, each contraction is Lipchitz and thus continuous [20]. It implies that :

If⁢xn⁢⟶||⋅||⁢x⁢then⁢𝒯⁢xn⁢⟶||⋅||⁢𝒯⁢x,\text{If}~{}~{}x_{n}\underset{||\cdot||}{\longrightarrow}x~{}~{}~{}\text{then}% ~{}~{}~{}\mathcal{T}x_{n}\underset{||\cdot||}{\longrightarrow}\mathcal{T}x,If italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_UNDERACCENT | | ⋅ | | end_UNDERACCENT start_ARG ⟶ end_ARG italic_x then caligraphic_T italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_UNDERACCENT | | ⋅ | | end_UNDERACCENT start_ARG ⟶ end_ARG caligraphic_T italic_x ,

where ⟶||⋅||\underset{||\cdot||}{\longrightarrow}start_UNDERACCENT | | ⋅ | | end_UNDERACCENT start_ARG ⟶ end_ARG denotes the convergence using that norm ||⋅||||\cdot||| | ⋅ | |. Now, by definition, an element x∗∈Xsuperscript𝑥𝑋x^{*}\in Xitalic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∈ italic_X is called fixed point for 𝒯𝒯\mathcal{T}caligraphic_T if we have :

𝒯⁢x∗=x∗𝒯superscript𝑥superscript𝑥\mathcal{T}x^{*}=x^{*}caligraphic_T italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT
4.1.3 Proposition.

Let (X,||⋅||)(X,||\cdot||)( italic_X , | | ⋅ | | ) be a Banach space and   𝒯:X→X:𝒯→𝑋𝑋\mathcal{T}:X\rightarrow Xcaligraphic_T : italic_X → italic_X    a    γ−contraction mapping𝛾contraction mapping\gamma-\text{contraction mapping}italic_γ - contraction mapping. Then :

  1. 1.

    𝒯𝒯\mathcal{T}caligraphic_T has a unique fixed point x∗∈Xsuperscript𝑥𝑋x^{*}\in Xitalic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∈ italic_X.

  2. 2.

    For every starting point x0∈Xsubscript𝑥0𝑋x_{0}\in Xitalic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ italic_X, the sequence recursively defined by xn+1=𝒯⁢xnsubscript𝑥𝑛1𝒯subscript𝑥𝑛x_{n+1}=\mathcal{T}x_{n}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = caligraphic_T italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT converges to x∗superscript𝑥x^{*}italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT in a geometric fashion.

Proof.

For the first part, see the proof of the Banach fixed point Theorem 2.2.5. Let’s now only justify the fact that the convergence is in geometric fashion :

𝒯⁢‖xn−1−x∗‖=‖𝒯⁢xn−1−𝒯⁢x∗‖=‖𝒯⁢xn−1−x∗‖=‖xn−x∗‖,𝒯normsubscript𝑥𝑛1superscript𝑥norm𝒯subscript𝑥𝑛1𝒯superscript𝑥norm𝒯subscript𝑥𝑛1superscript𝑥normsubscript𝑥𝑛superscript𝑥\mathcal{T}||x_{n-1}-x^{*}||=||\mathcal{T}x_{n-1}-\mathcal{T}x^{*}||=||% \mathcal{T}x_{n-1}-x^{*}||=||x_{n}-x^{*}||,caligraphic_T | | italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | | = | | caligraphic_T italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - caligraphic_T italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | | = | | caligraphic_T italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | | = | | italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | | ,

and as we are working with a contraction mapping, we also have ‖𝒯⁢xn−1−𝒯⁢x∗‖≤γ⋅‖xn−1−x∗‖norm𝒯subscript𝑥𝑛1𝒯superscript𝑥⋅𝛾normsubscript𝑥𝑛1superscript𝑥||\mathcal{T}x_{n-1}-\mathcal{T}x^{*}||\leq\gamma\cdot||x_{n-1}-x^{*}||| | caligraphic_T italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - caligraphic_T italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | | ≤ italic_γ ⋅ | | italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | |, then we can conclude directly ‖xn−x∗‖≤γ⋅‖xn−1−x∗‖normsubscript𝑥𝑛superscript𝑥⋅𝛾normsubscript𝑥𝑛1superscript𝑥||x_{n}-x^{*}||\leq\gamma\cdot||x_{n-1}-x^{*}||| | italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | | ≤ italic_γ ⋅ | | italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | |. Which implies that we get, by iteratively applying the mapping on the second member of this previous inequality, ‖xn−x∗‖≤γn⋅‖x0−x∗‖normsubscript𝑥𝑛superscript𝑥⋅superscript𝛾𝑛normsubscript𝑥0superscript𝑥||x_{n}-x^{*}||\leq\gamma^{n}\cdot||x_{0}-x^{*}||| | italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | | ≤ italic_γ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⋅ | | italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | | thus

limn→∞‖xn−x∗‖≤limn→∞(γn⋅‖x0−x∗‖)=0⇒limn→∞‖xn−x∗‖=0subscript→𝑛normsubscript𝑥𝑛superscript𝑥subscript→𝑛⋅superscript𝛾𝑛normsubscript𝑥0superscript𝑥0⇒subscript→𝑛normsubscript𝑥𝑛superscript𝑥0\lim_{n\to\infty}||x_{n}-x^{*}||\leq\lim_{n\to\infty}\left(\gamma^{n}\cdot||x_% {0}-x^{*}||\right)=0\Rightarrow\lim_{n\to\infty}||x_{n}-x^{*}||=0roman_lim start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n → ∞ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | | italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | | ≤ roman_lim start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n → ∞ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_γ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⋅ | | italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | | ) = 0 ⇒ roman_lim start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n → ∞ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | | italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | | = 0

∎

As we may have noticed, the Proposition 4.1.3, is the Banach Contraction Principle as given by the Theorem 2.2.5. We restrain it on Banach spaces because this is sufficient for the RL setting. In fact, in many instances encountered in Reinforcement Learning (RL), the vector space X𝑋Xitalic_X is frequently identified as ℝdsuperscriptℝ𝑑\mathbb{R}^{d}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT or the space of real bounded functions, and the most relevant norms are mostly ||⋅||2||\cdot||_{2}| | ⋅ | | start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and ||⋅||∞||\cdot||_{\infty}| | ⋅ | | start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∞ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. So, stating the theorem on Banach Spaces is sufficient in this setting.

4.2 Bellman Optimality Operators

Operators are maps in space of functions. Here we will be defining them with respect to the associated RL equations. Let’s first define the whole mathematical framework that we’ll be using here.
c
Let ℳ=⟨𝒮,𝒜,p,r,γ⟩ℳ𝒮𝒜𝑝𝑟𝛾\mathcal{M}=\langle\mathcal{S},\mathcal{A},p,r,\gamma\ranglecaligraphic_M = ⟨ caligraphic_S , caligraphic_A , italic_p , italic_r , italic_γ ⟩ be a Markov Decision Process (MDP), 𝒱s≡𝒱subscript𝒱𝑠𝒱\mathcal{V}_{s}\equiv\mathcal{V}caligraphic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≡ caligraphic_V the space of bounded real-valued functions over 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S}caligraphic_S and 𝒬𝒬\mathcal{Q}caligraphic_Q the space of bounded real-valued functions over 𝒮×𝒜𝒮𝒜\mathcal{S}\times\mathcal{A}caligraphic_S × caligraphic_A. With that we will call :

  • •

    𝒱𝒱\mathcal{V}caligraphic_V :    the space of all state-value functions,

  • •

    𝒬𝒬\mathcal{Q}caligraphic_Q :    the space of all action-value functions,

  • •

    (𝒯vπ):𝒱→𝒱:subscriptsuperscript𝒯𝜋𝑣→𝒱𝒱\left(\mathcal{T}^{\pi}_{v}\right):\mathcal{V}\rightarrow\mathcal{V}( caligraphic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_π end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) : caligraphic_V → caligraphic_V    the Bellman Expectation Operator for the state value function,

  • •

    (𝒯Qπ):Q→Q:subscriptsuperscript𝒯𝜋𝑄→𝑄𝑄\left(\mathcal{T}^{\pi}_{Q}\right):Q\rightarrow Q( caligraphic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_π end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) : italic_Q → italic_Q :    the Bellman Expectation Operator for the action-value function,

  • •

    (𝒯v∗):𝒱→𝒱:subscriptsuperscript𝒯𝑣→𝒱𝒱\left(\mathcal{T}^{*}_{v}\right):\mathcal{V}\rightarrow\mathcal{V}( caligraphic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) : caligraphic_V → caligraphic_V    the Bellman Optimality Operator for the state value function,

  • •

    (𝒯Q∗):Q→Q:subscriptsuperscript𝒯𝑄→𝑄𝑄\left(\mathcal{T}^{*}_{Q}\right):Q\rightarrow Q( caligraphic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) : italic_Q → italic_Q :    the Bellman Optimality for the action-value function

  • •

    π:𝒮→Δ⁢(𝒜):𝜋→𝒮Δ𝒜\pi:\mathcal{S}\rightarrow\Delta\left(\mathcal{A}\right)italic_π : caligraphic_S → roman_Δ ( caligraphic_A )    the policy (a conditional probability defined by π⁢(a|s)=P⁢r⁢{a|s}𝜋conditional𝑎𝑠𝑃𝑟conditional-set𝑎𝑠\pi(a|s)=Pr\{a|s\}italic_π ( italic_a | italic_s ) = italic_P italic_r { italic_a | italic_s }) with Δ⁢(𝒜)Δ𝒜\Delta\left(\mathcal{A}\right)roman_Δ ( caligraphic_A ) denoting a probability distribution of actions.

Inspired by the definition given in the Expression 2.1.3 and the Example 2.1.14 we know that, with ‖f⁢(s)‖∞≡max𝑠⁢|f⁢(s)|subscriptnorm𝑓𝑠𝑠𝑓𝑠||f(s)||_{\infty}\equiv\underset{s}{\max}|f(s)|| | italic_f ( italic_s ) | | start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∞ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≡ underitalic_s start_ARG roman_max end_ARG | italic_f ( italic_s ) |, the tuple (𝒱,||.||∞)(\mathcal{V},||.||_{\infty})( caligraphic_V , | | . | | start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∞ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) is a Banach Space.
Also, with ‖f⁢(s,a)‖∞≡maxs,a⁢|f⁢(s,a)|subscriptnorm𝑓𝑠𝑎𝑠𝑎𝑓𝑠𝑎||f(s,a)||_{\infty}\equiv\underset{s,a}{\max}|f(s,a)|| | italic_f ( italic_s , italic_a ) | | start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∞ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≡ start_UNDERACCENT italic_s , italic_a end_UNDERACCENT start_ARG roman_max end_ARG | italic_f ( italic_s , italic_a ) | we can also see that (𝒬,||.||∞)(\mathcal{Q},||.||_{\infty})( caligraphic_Q , | | . | | start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∞ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) is a Banach Space. Those two supremum norms are different but we will be writing them in the same way because, the real formula will depend on the space we are working with.

4.2.1 Definition.

Let’s recall the fact that, the Bellman Optimality equation for the value function (Relation 3.2.5) is given by the following expression :

v∗⁢(s)=max𝑎⁢(r⁢(s,a)+γ⋅∑s′p⁢(s′|s,a)⋅v∗⁢(s′))subscript𝑣𝑠𝑎𝑟𝑠𝑎⋅𝛾subscriptsuperscript𝑠′⋅𝑝conditionalsuperscript𝑠′𝑠𝑎subscript𝑣superscript𝑠′v_{*}(s)=\underset{a}{\max}\Big{(}r(s,a)+\gamma\cdot\sum_{s^{\prime}}p(s^{% \prime}|s,a)\cdot v_{*}(s^{\prime})\Big{)}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_s ) = underitalic_a start_ARG roman_max end_ARG ( italic_r ( italic_s , italic_a ) + italic_γ ⋅ ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p ( italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | italic_s , italic_a ) ⋅ italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) )

By analogy, we will define, point-wise, the Bellman Optimality Operator for state value function (𝒯v∗):𝒱→𝒱:subscriptsuperscript𝒯𝑣→𝒱𝒱\left(\mathcal{T}^{*}_{v}\right):\mathcal{V}\rightarrow\mathcal{V}( caligraphic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) : caligraphic_V → caligraphic_V by :

(𝒯v∗⁢f)⁢(s)≡max𝑎⁢[r⁢(s,a)+γ⋅∑s′p⁢(s′|s,a)⋅f⁢(s′)]⁢∀f∈𝒱subscriptsuperscript𝒯𝑣𝑓𝑠𝑎delimited-[]𝑟𝑠𝑎⋅𝛾subscriptsuperscript𝑠′⋅𝑝conditionalsuperscript𝑠′𝑠𝑎𝑓superscript𝑠′for-all𝑓𝒱\left(\mathcal{T}^{*}_{v}f\right)(s)\equiv\underset{a}{\max}\left[r(s,a)+% \gamma\cdot\sum_{s^{\prime}}p(s^{\prime}|s,a)\cdot f(s^{\prime})\right]~{}~{}~% {}\forall f\in\mathcal{V}( caligraphic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f ) ( italic_s ) ≡ underitalic_a start_ARG roman_max end_ARG [ italic_r ( italic_s , italic_a ) + italic_γ ⋅ ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p ( italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | italic_s , italic_a ) ⋅ italic_f ( italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ] ∀ italic_f ∈ caligraphic_V (4.2.1)

4.2.2 Properties of this operator

The convention we’ll take here is to write (𝒯v∗)subscriptsuperscript𝒯𝑣\left(\mathcal{T}^{*}_{v}\right)( caligraphic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) just (𝒯∗)superscript𝒯\left(\mathcal{T}^{*}\right)( caligraphic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ), knowing that the space will be written 𝒱𝒱\mathcal{V}caligraphic_V by default. Now, what is very interesting is that, the operator, defined in Relation 4.2.1 has these properties [2] :

  • •

    𝒯∗superscript𝒯\mathcal{T}^{*}caligraphic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is a γ−limit-from𝛾\gamma-italic_γ -contraction with respect to the supremum norm ||⋅||∞||\cdot||_{\infty}| | ⋅ | | start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∞ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT on 𝒱𝒱\mathcal{V}caligraphic_V :

    ‖𝒯∗⁢u−𝒯∗⁢v‖∞≤γ⋅‖u−v‖∞⁢∀u,v∈𝒱⁢with γ∈[0,1)formulae-sequencesubscriptnormsuperscript𝒯𝑢superscript𝒯𝑣⋅𝛾subscriptnorm𝑢𝑣for-all𝑢𝑣𝒱with γ∈[0,1)||\mathcal{T}^{*}u-\mathcal{T}^{*}v||_{\infty}\leq\gamma\cdot||u-v||_{\infty}~% {}~{}\forall~{}u,v\in\mathcal{V}~{}~{}~{}\text{with $\gamma\in[0,1)$}| | caligraphic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_u - caligraphic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_v | | start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∞ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≤ italic_γ ⋅ | | italic_u - italic_v | | start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∞ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∀ italic_u , italic_v ∈ caligraphic_V with italic_γ ∈ [ 0 , 1 )
  • •

    𝒯∗superscript𝒯\mathcal{T}^{*}caligraphic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is monotonic :

    ∀u,v∈𝒱⁢s.t⁢u≤v,in any state,⁢𝒯∗⁢u≤𝒯∗⁢vformulae-sequencefor-all𝑢𝑣𝒱s.t𝑢𝑣in any state,superscript𝒯𝑢superscript𝒯𝑣\forall~{}u,v\in\mathcal{V}~{}\text{s.t}~{}u\leq v,~{}\text{in any state,}~{}~% {}\mathcal{T}^{*}u\leq\mathcal{T}^{*}v∀ italic_u , italic_v ∈ caligraphic_V s.t italic_u ≤ italic_v , in any state, caligraphic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_u ≤ caligraphic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_v
Proof.

First, let us rewrite simply the Bellman Optimality Operator in Relation 4.2.1 like this :

(𝒯v∗⁢f)⁢(s)≡(𝒯∗⁢f)⁢(s)≡max𝑎⁢[r⁢(s,a)+γ⋅𝔼s′|s,a⁢f⁢(s′)]subscriptsuperscript𝒯𝑣𝑓𝑠superscript𝒯𝑓𝑠𝑎delimited-[]𝑟𝑠𝑎⋅𝛾subscript𝔼conditionalsuperscript𝑠′𝑠𝑎𝑓superscript𝑠′\left(\mathcal{T}^{*}_{v}f\right)(s)\equiv\left(\mathcal{T}^{*}f\right)(s)% \equiv\underset{a}{\max}\Big{[}r(s,a)+\gamma\cdot\mathbb{E}_{s^{\prime}|s,a}f(% s^{\prime})\Big{]}( caligraphic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f ) ( italic_s ) ≡ ( caligraphic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_f ) ( italic_s ) ≡ underitalic_a start_ARG roman_max end_ARG [ italic_r ( italic_s , italic_a ) + italic_γ ⋅ blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | italic_s , italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f ( italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ] (4.2.2)

Now, let us prove the two properties of the Bellman Optimality Operator 𝒯∗superscript𝒯\mathcal{T}^{*}caligraphic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT :

  1. 1.

    Using the definition of a contraction mapping and Bellman Optimality Operator we expand :

    |𝒯∗⁢u⁢(s)−𝒯∗⁢v⁢(s)|=|max𝑎⁢[r⁢(s,a)+γ⋅𝔼s′|s,a⁢u⁢(s′)]−max𝑏⁢[r⁢(s,b)+γ⋅𝔼s′|s,b⁢v⁢(s′)]|superscript𝒯𝑢𝑠superscript𝒯𝑣𝑠𝑎delimited-[]𝑟𝑠𝑎⋅𝛾subscript𝔼conditionalsuperscript𝑠′𝑠𝑎𝑢superscript𝑠′𝑏delimited-[]𝑟𝑠𝑏⋅𝛾subscript𝔼conditionalsuperscript𝑠′𝑠𝑏𝑣superscript𝑠′\left|\mathcal{T}^{*}u(s)-\mathcal{T}^{*}v(s)\right|=\left|\underset{a}{\max}% \left[r(s,a)+\gamma\cdot\mathbb{E}_{s^{\prime}|s,a}u(s^{\prime})\right]-% \underset{b}{\max}\left[r(s,b)+\gamma\cdot\mathbb{E}_{s^{\prime}|s,b}v(s^{% \prime})\right]\right|| caligraphic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_u ( italic_s ) - caligraphic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_v ( italic_s ) | = | underitalic_a start_ARG roman_max end_ARG [ italic_r ( italic_s , italic_a ) + italic_γ ⋅ blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | italic_s , italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u ( italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ] - underitalic_b start_ARG roman_max end_ARG [ italic_r ( italic_s , italic_b ) + italic_γ ⋅ blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | italic_s , italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v ( italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ] |

    Since for f,g𝑓𝑔f,gitalic_f , italic_g real-valued functions, |max𝑥⁢f⁢(x)−max𝑥⁢g⁢(x)|≤max𝑥⁢|f⁢(x)−g⁢(x)|𝑥𝑓𝑥𝑥𝑔𝑥𝑥𝑓𝑥𝑔𝑥|\underset{x}{\max}f(x)-\underset{x}{\max}g(x)|\leq\underset{x}{\max}|f(x)-g(x)|| underitalic_x start_ARG roman_max end_ARG italic_f ( italic_x ) - underitalic_x start_ARG roman_max end_ARG italic_g ( italic_x ) | ≤ underitalic_x start_ARG roman_max end_ARG | italic_f ( italic_x ) - italic_g ( italic_x ) |, it follows that :

    |𝒯∗⁢u⁢(s)−𝒯∗⁢v⁢(s)|superscript𝒯𝑢𝑠superscript𝒯𝑣𝑠\displaystyle\left|\mathcal{T}^{*}u(s)-\mathcal{T}^{*}v(s)\right|| caligraphic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_u ( italic_s ) - caligraphic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_v ( italic_s ) | ≤max𝑎⁢|[r⁢(s,a)+γ⋅𝔼s′|s,a⁢u⁢(s′)]−[r⁢(s,a)+γ⋅𝔼s′|s,a⁢v⁢(s′)]|absent𝑎delimited-[]𝑟𝑠𝑎⋅𝛾subscript𝔼conditionalsuperscript𝑠′𝑠𝑎𝑢superscript𝑠′delimited-[]𝑟𝑠𝑎⋅𝛾subscript𝔼conditionalsuperscript𝑠′𝑠𝑎𝑣superscript𝑠′\displaystyle\leq\underset{a}{\max}\big{|}\left[r(s,a)+\gamma\cdot\mathbb{E}_{% s^{\prime}|s,a}u(s^{\prime})\right]-\left[r(s,a)+\gamma\cdot\mathbb{E}_{s^{% \prime}|s,a}v(s^{\prime})\right]\big{|}≤ underitalic_a start_ARG roman_max end_ARG | [ italic_r ( italic_s , italic_a ) + italic_γ ⋅ blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | italic_s , italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u ( italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ] - [ italic_r ( italic_s , italic_a ) + italic_γ ⋅ blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | italic_s , italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v ( italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ] |
    =max𝑎⁢|γ⋅𝔼s′|s,a⁢u⁢(s′)−γ⋅𝔼s′|s,a⁢v⁢(s′)|absent𝑎⋅𝛾subscript𝔼conditionalsuperscript𝑠′𝑠𝑎𝑢superscript𝑠′⋅𝛾subscript𝔼conditionalsuperscript𝑠′𝑠𝑎𝑣superscript𝑠′\displaystyle=\underset{a}{\max}\big{|}\gamma\cdot\mathbb{E}_{s^{\prime}|s,a}u% (s^{\prime})-\gamma\cdot\mathbb{E}_{s^{\prime}|s,a}v(s^{\prime})\big{|}= underitalic_a start_ARG roman_max end_ARG | italic_γ ⋅ blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | italic_s , italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u ( italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) - italic_γ ⋅ blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | italic_s , italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v ( italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) |
    =max𝑎⁢(γ⋅|𝔼s′|s,a⁢(u⁢(s′)−v⁢(s′))|)absent𝑎⋅𝛾subscript𝔼conditionalsuperscript𝑠′𝑠𝑎𝑢superscript𝑠′𝑣superscript𝑠′\displaystyle=\underset{a}{\max}\left(\gamma\cdot\big{|}\mathbb{E}_{s^{\prime}% |s,a}\left(u(s^{\prime})-v(s^{\prime})\right)\big{|}\right)= underitalic_a start_ARG roman_max end_ARG ( italic_γ ⋅ | blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | italic_s , italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_u ( italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) - italic_v ( italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ) | )
    ≤maxs′⁢|γ⋅(u⁢(s′)−v⁢(s′))|absentsuperscript𝑠′⋅𝛾𝑢superscript𝑠′𝑣superscript𝑠′\displaystyle\leq\underset{s^{\prime}}{\max}\big{|}\gamma\cdot\left(u(s^{% \prime})-v(s^{\prime})\right)\big{|}≤ start_UNDERACCENT italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_UNDERACCENT start_ARG roman_max end_ARG | italic_γ ⋅ ( italic_u ( italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) - italic_v ( italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ) |
    =γ⋅max𝑠⁢|(u⁢(s)−v⁢(s))|absent⋅𝛾𝑠𝑢𝑠𝑣𝑠\displaystyle=\gamma\cdot\underset{s}{\max}\big{|}\left(u(s)-v(s)\right)\big{|}= italic_γ ⋅ underitalic_s start_ARG roman_max end_ARG | ( italic_u ( italic_s ) - italic_v ( italic_s ) ) |
    ⇒|𝒯∗⁢u⁢(s)−𝒯∗⁢v⁢(s)|⇒absentsuperscript𝒯𝑢𝑠superscript𝒯𝑣𝑠\displaystyle\Rightarrow\left|\mathcal{T}^{*}u(s)-\mathcal{T}^{*}v(s)\right|⇒ | caligraphic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_u ( italic_s ) - caligraphic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_v ( italic_s ) | ≤γ⋅‖u−v‖∞absent⋅𝛾subscriptnorm𝑢𝑣\displaystyle\leq\gamma\cdot||u-v||_{\infty}≤ italic_γ ⋅ | | italic_u - italic_v | | start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∞ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT
    ⇒max𝑠⁢|𝒯∗⁢u⁢(s)−𝒯∗⁢v⁢(s)|⇒absent𝑠superscript𝒯𝑢𝑠superscript𝒯𝑣𝑠\displaystyle\Rightarrow\underset{s}{\max}\left|\mathcal{T}^{*}u(s)-\mathcal{T% }^{*}v(s)\right|⇒ underitalic_s start_ARG roman_max end_ARG | caligraphic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_u ( italic_s ) - caligraphic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_v ( italic_s ) | ≤γ⋅‖u−v‖∞absent⋅𝛾subscriptnorm𝑢𝑣\displaystyle\leq\gamma\cdot||u-v||_{\infty}≤ italic_γ ⋅ | | italic_u - italic_v | | start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∞ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT
    ⇒‖𝒯∗⁢u⁢(s)−𝒯∗⁢v⁢(s)‖∞⇒absentsubscriptnormsuperscript𝒯𝑢𝑠superscript𝒯𝑣𝑠\displaystyle\Rightarrow||\mathcal{T}^{*}u(s)-\mathcal{T}^{*}v(s)||_{\infty}⇒ | | caligraphic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_u ( italic_s ) - caligraphic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_v ( italic_s ) | | start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∞ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≤γ⋅‖u−v‖∞absent⋅𝛾subscriptnorm𝑢𝑣\displaystyle\leq\gamma\cdot||u-v||_{\infty}≤ italic_γ ⋅ | | italic_u - italic_v | | start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∞ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (4.2.3)
  2. 2.

    We can now prove the monotonicity very simply :

    Assume that for all s𝑠sitalic_s, v⁢(s)≤u⁢(s)𝑣𝑠𝑢𝑠v(s)\leq u(s)italic_v ( italic_s ) ≤ italic_u ( italic_s ). Then r⁢(s,a)+γ⋅𝔼s′|s,a⁢v⁢(s′)≤r⁢(s,a)+γ⋅𝔼s′|s,a⁢u⁢(s′)𝑟𝑠𝑎⋅𝛾subscript𝔼conditionalsuperscript𝑠′𝑠𝑎𝑣superscript𝑠′𝑟𝑠𝑎⋅𝛾subscript𝔼conditionalsuperscript𝑠′𝑠𝑎𝑢superscript𝑠′r(s,a)+\gamma\cdot\mathbb{E}_{s^{\prime}|s,a}v(s^{\prime})\leq r(s,a)+\gamma% \cdot\mathbb{E}_{s^{\prime}|s,a}u(s^{\prime})italic_r ( italic_s , italic_a ) + italic_γ ⋅ blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | italic_s , italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v ( italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ≤ italic_r ( italic_s , italic_a ) + italic_γ ⋅ blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | italic_s , italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u ( italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ).

    Let us evaluate 𝒯∗⁢v⁢(s)−𝒯∗⁢u⁢(s)superscript𝒯𝑣𝑠superscript𝒯𝑢𝑠\mathcal{T}^{*}v(s)-\mathcal{T}^{*}u(s)caligraphic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_v ( italic_s ) - caligraphic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_u ( italic_s ) and see what happens :

    𝒯∗⁢v⁢(s)−𝒯∗⁢u⁢(s)superscript𝒯𝑣𝑠superscript𝒯𝑢𝑠\displaystyle\mathcal{T}^{*}v(s)-\mathcal{T}^{*}u(s)~{}caligraphic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_v ( italic_s ) - caligraphic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_u ( italic_s ) =max𝑎⁢[r⁢(s,a)+γ⋅𝔼s′|s,a⁢v⁢(s′)]−max𝑎⁢[r⁢(s,a)+γ⋅𝔼s′|s,a⁢u⁢(s′)]absent𝑎delimited-[]𝑟𝑠𝑎⋅𝛾subscript𝔼conditionalsuperscript𝑠′𝑠𝑎𝑣superscript𝑠′𝑎delimited-[]𝑟𝑠𝑎⋅𝛾subscript𝔼conditionalsuperscript𝑠′𝑠𝑎𝑢superscript𝑠′\displaystyle=\underset{a}{\max}\left[r(s,a)+\gamma\cdot\mathbb{E}_{s^{\prime}% |s,a}v(s^{\prime})\right]-\underset{a}{\max}\left[r(s,a)+\gamma\cdot\mathbb{E}% _{s^{\prime}|s,a}u(s^{\prime})\right]= underitalic_a start_ARG roman_max end_ARG [ italic_r ( italic_s , italic_a ) + italic_γ ⋅ blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | italic_s , italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v ( italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ] - underitalic_a start_ARG roman_max end_ARG [ italic_r ( italic_s , italic_a ) + italic_γ ⋅ blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | italic_s , italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u ( italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ]
    ≤max𝑎⁢([r⁢(s,a)+γ⋅𝔼s′|s,a⁢v⁢(s′)]−[r⁢(s,a)+γ⋅𝔼s′|s,a⁢u⁢(s′)]⏟≤0)absent𝑎absent0⏟delimited-[]𝑟𝑠𝑎⋅𝛾subscript𝔼conditionalsuperscript𝑠′𝑠𝑎𝑣superscript𝑠′delimited-[]𝑟𝑠𝑎⋅𝛾subscript𝔼conditionalsuperscript𝑠′𝑠𝑎𝑢superscript𝑠′\displaystyle\leq\underset{a}{\max}\Big{(}\underset{\leq~{}~{}0}{\underbrace{% \left[r(s,a)+\gamma\cdot\mathbb{E}_{s^{\prime}|s,a}v(s^{\prime})\right]-\left[% r(s,a)+\gamma\cdot\mathbb{E}_{s^{\prime}|s,a}u(s^{\prime})\right]}}\Big{)}≤ underitalic_a start_ARG roman_max end_ARG ( start_UNDERACCENT ≤ 0 end_UNDERACCENT start_ARG under⏟ start_ARG [ italic_r ( italic_s , italic_a ) + italic_γ ⋅ blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | italic_s , italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v ( italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ] - [ italic_r ( italic_s , italic_a ) + italic_γ ⋅ blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | italic_s , italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u ( italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ] end_ARG end_ARG )
    𝒯∗⁢v⁢(s)−𝒯∗⁢u⁢(s)superscript𝒯𝑣𝑠superscript𝒯𝑢𝑠\displaystyle\mathcal{T}^{*}v(s)-\mathcal{T}^{*}u(s)~{}caligraphic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_v ( italic_s ) - caligraphic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_u ( italic_s ) ≤0absent0\displaystyle\leq~{}~{}0≤ 0
    ⇒𝒯∗⁢v⁢(s)⇒absentsuperscript𝒯𝑣𝑠\displaystyle\Rightarrow\mathcal{T}^{*}v(s)~{}~{}⇒ caligraphic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_v ( italic_s ) ≤𝒯∗⁢u⁢(s)⁢∀sabsentsuperscript𝒯𝑢𝑠for-all𝑠\displaystyle\leq~{}~{}\mathcal{T}^{*}u(s)~{}~{}~{}\forall~{}s≤ caligraphic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_u ( italic_s ) ∀ italic_s (4.2.4)

∎

Now, using the Banach Contraction Principle as refined by the Proposition 4.1.3, we can conclude that, the Bellman Optimality Operator 𝒯∗superscript𝒯\mathcal{T}^{*}caligraphic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT on (𝒱,||⋅||∞)(\mathcal{V},||\cdot||_{\infty})( caligraphic_V , | | ⋅ | | start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∞ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) has the following behaviors :

  • •

    𝒯∗superscript𝒯\mathcal{T}^{*}caligraphic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT has a unique fixed point f∗∈𝒱superscript𝑓𝒱f^{*}\in\mathcal{V}italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∈ caligraphic_V.

  • •

    For any starting point (function) f0subscript𝑓0f_{0}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, we can find the fixed point f∗superscript𝑓f^{*}italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT by looking for the convergence of the sequence defined by fn+1=𝒯⁢fnsubscript𝑓𝑛1𝒯subscript𝑓𝑛f_{n+1}=\mathcal{T}f_{n}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = caligraphic_T italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.
    Also, the fixed point that we will find will be the optimal value function, since it’ll be the maximum (in fact, this sequence is monotonically increasing by our definition of the problem).

This fixed point f∗superscript𝑓f^{*}italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is the overall optimal value function because here the equation use exactly the optimal policy π∗superscript𝜋\pi^{*}italic_π start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.
We can, in the same way, define the operator for action-value functions.

4.2.3 Definition.

As we know, the Bellman Optimality equation for Q-values (Relation 3.2.6) is given by this expression :

q∗⁢(s,a)=r⁢(s,a)+γ⋅∑s′p⁢(s′|s,a)⋅maxa′⁢q∗⁢(s′,a′)subscript𝑞𝑠𝑎𝑟𝑠𝑎⋅𝛾subscriptsuperscript𝑠′⋅𝑝conditionalsuperscript𝑠′𝑠𝑎superscript𝑎′subscript𝑞superscript𝑠′superscript𝑎′q_{*}(s,a)=r(s,a)+\gamma\cdot\sum_{s^{\prime}}p(s^{\prime}|s,a)\cdot\underset{% a^{\prime}}{\max}~{}{q_{*}(s^{\prime},a^{\prime})}italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_s , italic_a ) = italic_r ( italic_s , italic_a ) + italic_γ ⋅ ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p ( italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | italic_s , italic_a ) ⋅ start_UNDERACCENT italic_a start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_UNDERACCENT start_ARG roman_max end_ARG italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_a start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT )

Now, giving the same MDP ℳℳ\mathcal{M}caligraphic_M, let 𝒬𝒬\mathcal{Q}caligraphic_Q be the space of bounded real-valued functions over 𝒮×𝒜𝒮𝒜\mathcal{S}\times\mathcal{A}caligraphic_S × caligraphic_A.
We can also define, point-wise, the Bellman Optimality Operator for the Q-Value 𝒯Q∗:Q→Q:subscriptsuperscript𝒯𝑄→𝑄𝑄\mathcal{T}^{*}_{Q}:Q\rightarrow Qcaligraphic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT : italic_Q → italic_Q as follows :

(𝒯Q∗⁢f)⁢(s,a)≡r⁢(s,a)+γ⋅∑s′[p⁢(s′|s,a)⋅maxa′∈𝒜⁢(s′)⁢f⁢(s′,a′)]⁢∀f∈𝒬subscriptsuperscript𝒯𝑄𝑓𝑠𝑎𝑟𝑠𝑎⋅𝛾subscriptsuperscript𝑠′delimited-[]⋅𝑝conditionalsuperscript𝑠′𝑠𝑎superscript𝑎′𝒜superscript𝑠′𝑓superscript𝑠′superscript𝑎′for-all𝑓𝒬\left(\mathcal{T}^{*}_{Q}f\right)(s,a)\equiv r(s,a)+\gamma\cdot\sum_{s^{\prime% }}\left[p(s^{\prime}|s,a)\cdot\underset{a^{\prime}\in\mathcal{A}(s^{\prime})}{% \max}f(s^{\prime},a^{\prime})\right]~{}~{}~{}\forall f\in\mathcal{Q}( caligraphic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f ) ( italic_s , italic_a ) ≡ italic_r ( italic_s , italic_a ) + italic_γ ⋅ ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_p ( italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | italic_s , italic_a ) ⋅ start_UNDERACCENT italic_a start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∈ caligraphic_A ( italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) end_UNDERACCENT start_ARG roman_max end_ARG italic_f ( italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_a start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ] ∀ italic_f ∈ caligraphic_Q (4.2.5)

The same properties can be stated for this Bellman optimality operator for the Q-value, using the same kind of proofs.
The Bellman optimality operators as defined here are particular cases of what we will refer to as Bellman Expectation Operators. In this context, we considered the scenario of selecting the action that maximises the expected reward, without consideration of alternative policies. We now consider the policy in more general terms. This does not lead only to the optimal value function, but also to the value function corresponding to the chosen policy.

4.3 Bellman Expectation Operators

We will start with the state-value Bellman Expectation Operator. We know that, the Bellman Expectation equation is given by the Relation 3.1.15 :

vπ⁢(s)=∑aπ⁢(a|s)⋅(r⁢(s,a)+γ⋅∑s′p⁢(s′|s,a)⁢vπ⁢(s′))subscript𝑣𝜋𝑠subscript𝑎⋅𝜋conditional𝑎𝑠𝑟𝑠𝑎⋅𝛾subscriptsuperscript𝑠′𝑝conditionalsuperscript𝑠′𝑠𝑎subscript𝑣𝜋superscript𝑠′v_{\pi}(s)=\sum_{a}\pi(a|s)\cdot\left(r(s,a)+\gamma\cdot\sum_{s^{\prime}}p(s^{% \prime}|s,a)v_{\pi}(s^{\prime})\right)italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_π end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_s ) = ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_π ( italic_a | italic_s ) ⋅ ( italic_r ( italic_s , italic_a ) + italic_γ ⋅ ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p ( italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | italic_s , italic_a ) italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_π end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) )

We can define by analogy the Bellman Expectation Operator by :

(𝒯vπ⁢f)⁢(s)=∑aπ⁢(a|s)⋅(r⁢(s,a)+γ⋅∑s′p⁢(s′|s,a)⁢f⁢(s′))⁢∀f∈𝒱subscriptsuperscript𝒯𝜋𝑣𝑓𝑠subscript𝑎⋅𝜋conditional𝑎𝑠𝑟𝑠𝑎⋅𝛾subscriptsuperscript𝑠′𝑝conditionalsuperscript𝑠′𝑠𝑎𝑓superscript𝑠′for-all𝑓𝒱\left(\mathcal{T}^{\pi}_{v}f\right)(s)=\sum_{a}\pi(a|s)\cdot\left(r(s,a)+% \gamma\cdot\sum_{s^{\prime}}p(s^{\prime}|s,a)f(s^{\prime})\right)~{}~{}\forall f% \in\mathcal{V}( caligraphic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_π end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f ) ( italic_s ) = ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_π ( italic_a | italic_s ) ⋅ ( italic_r ( italic_s , italic_a ) + italic_γ ⋅ ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p ( italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | italic_s , italic_a ) italic_f ( italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ) ∀ italic_f ∈ caligraphic_V (4.3.1)
4.3.1 Proposition.

We claim that, the operator 𝒯vπsubscriptsuperscript𝒯𝜋𝑣\mathcal{T}^{\pi}_{v}caligraphic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_π end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, as defined by the Expression 4.3.1 is :

  1. 1.

    A γ−limit-from𝛾\gamma-italic_γ -contraction mapping.

  2. 2.

    A monotonic mapping.

Proof.

Let consider two value functions u𝑢uitalic_u and v𝑣vitalic_v in 𝒱𝒱\mathcal{V}caligraphic_V.

  1. 1.
